   A.   Appointment: The mayor, with the consent of the council, shall appoint
the chief of police and the authorized policemen provided for in section
4-1-1 of this chapter, and he shall have authority, with the consent of the
council, to appoint special policemen from time to time as exigencies arise.
(1974 Code § 1-702)
   B.   Qualifications: Any person appointed as an officer or member of the
police department shall be a citizen of the United States. (1974 Code § 1-705)
   C.   Members Under Chief: All persons appointed under the provisions of this
chapter as policemen or special police shall be under the direction and
supervision of the chief of police.
   D.   Assistant Chief: The chief of police shall designate one of the
policemen to be assistant chief of police and, in the absence of the chief of
police, he shall have all the authority herein vested in the chief of police.
   E.   Duties: The policemen shall be subject to the orders of the chief of
police, except in cases otherwise provided by ordinance, it shall be their duty
to cause the public peace to be preserved and to see that all laws and
ordinances are enforced within the city limits. When violation of any law or
ordinance shall be reported to them or come to their knowledge, they shall
cause the required complaint to be made and see that all possible evidence is
procured for the successful prosecution of the offenders. (1974 Code § 1-703)
4-1-3: CHIEF OF POLICE MONTHLY REPORT:
The chief of police shall make a written report monthly giving a true account
of the number of arrests made, persons arrested and nature of offenses charged
during the month and such further reports as may at any time be required by the
mayor and council. (1974 Code § 1-704)
4-1-4: STANDARD OF TRAINING:
Pursuant to Idaho Code section 19-5110, the city, while receiving aid from the
peace officers standards and training council pursuant to Idaho Code title 19,
chapter 51, will adhere to the standards for employment and training
established by the peace officers standards and training council. (1974 Code §
1-706; amd. 2010 Code)
4-1-5: POWERS:
   A.   Arrest Offenders:
      1.   Manner Of Arrest: The officers and members of the police department
shall have power to arrest all offenders against the laws of the state, or of
the city, by day or by night, in the same manner as the sheriff or constable,
and keep them in the county jail or other place to prevent their escape until
trial can be had before the proper officer.
      2.   Pursuit Beyond Corporate Limits: Whenever such police officers shall
be in the fresh pursuit of an offender against any law of the state or of the
city, and the offense has been committed within the corporate limits of the
city, such police officers, while in fresh pursuit, may go beyond the corporate
or geographical limits of the city but not beyond the boundary lines of the
county of Twin Falls for the purpose of making such arrest. Upon overtaking
such offender outside the corporate or geographical limits of the city, the
arresting officer may take such offender to and keep him in the county jail, or
other place, to prevent his escape until trial can be had before the proper
officer, or may personally hand such arrested person a notice, in writing, or
partly written and partly printed, to appear in court of proper jurisdiction at
a time specified in such notice. (1974 Code § 1-707; amd. 2010 Code)
   B.   Call Others To Assist; Penalty For Refusal:
      1.   Authority To Call For Assistance: The chief of police or any member
of the police department shall have authority to call upon any person to assist
him in making an arrest, capturing or retaining in custody any person.
      2.   Refusal Or Failure To Assist: Any person, when so requested, who
shall refuse or fail, to the best of his ability, to render such aid as
required, shall be guilty of an offense, and, upon conviction thereof, shall be
subject to penalty as provided in section
1-4-1 of this code. (1974 Code § 1-708; amd. 2010 Code)
   C.   Remove And Impound Vehicles:
      1.    Authority To Remove And Impound: The police department of the city
is hereby authorized to remove and impound or cause to be removed and impounded
any vehicle parked in violation of any ordinance of the city. The owner or
operator of any such vehicle may recover the same by paying the cost of its
removal and impoundment, together with the sums due by reason of the violation
of said city ordinance. (1974 Code § 1-709; amd. 2010 Code)
      2.   Required Notice: Upon removal of a vehicle from public or private
property under subsection C1 of this section, the officer causing the vehicle
to be removed, shall immediately advise the department of law enforcement of
the state of Idaho of any identifying number or marks and attempt thereby to
determine the name of any owner or lienholder listed on the certificate of
title filed with the department of law enforcement. If there is no certificate
of title on file in the department, then a notice shall be sent to the apparent
owner as determined by the registration certificate or other identification
found in the vehicle, but if no identification of the owner can be found in the
vehicle then notice shall be given by publication in the official newspaper,
and in either event, the notice shall include: a) the make, year, model, color
and license plate, number of the vehicle; b) the approximate place where the
vehicle was found; c) the place to where the vehicle was removed; and d) a
statement that the vehicle will be sold for removal and storage charges if not
claimed within ten (10) days from the date of mailing or publication of the
notice.
   D.   Impounded Vehicles:
      1.   Claimed By Owner: Any person claiming ownership of any said vehicle,
upon producing a certificate of title or any other satisfactory documentary
evidence of ownership, shall be presented with his or her vehicle upon payment
of all costs of both removal and impoundment incurred by the city.
      2.   Sale Of Unclaimed Vehicles: In the event no person claims and pays
for any such vehicle so removed within ten (10) days either after personal
service of notice or publication of notice in the official newspaper, then it
shall be the duty of the chief of police to see that the impounded vehicle
shall be sold at either public or private sale. Proceeds of any such sale shall
be first applied to the city's costs in removal and impoundment and the
balance, if any there may be, shall then be remitted to the owner if he can be
found and otherwise any remaining money shall be forfeited to and become a part
of the general fund of the city. (1974 Code § 1-709)
CHAPTER 2
FIRE DEPARTMENT
SECTION:
4-2-1: Department Created
4-2-2: Officers And Personnel; Appointment
4-2-3: Chief Of Fire Department
4-2-4: Officers And Employees; Duties
4-2-5: Police; Duties At Fire
4-2-6: Equipment
4-2-7: Limit On Approach To Fire
4-2-8: Driving Across Hose Or Interference With Equipment
4-2-9: Violation; Penalty
4-2-1: DEPARTMENT CREATED:
There is hereby organized a fire department of the city, for the purpose of
protecting property and the lives of the citizens of said city. (1974 Code § 1-
601)
4-2-2: OFFICERS AND PERSONNEL; APPOINTMENT:
The officers and employees of the fire department of the city shall consist of
a chief of the fire department, an assistant chief of the fire department and
such officers and members as shall be authorized by the mayor and council. The
chief and the assistant chief of the fire department shall be appointed by the
mayor, with the advice and consent of the council. All other officers and
employees of the department shall be appointed by the mayor, with the advice
and consent of the council, upon the recommendation of the chief of the fire
department. (1974 Code § 1-603)
4-2-3: CHIEF OF FIRE DEPARTMENT:
   A.   Duties:
      1.   The chief of the fire department shall at all times, except in case
of absence or inability to act, have full charge of the entire fire department,
and at all times shall be subject to such rules as the mayor and the city
council shall prescribe. It shall be his duty to see that all officers and
employees of the fire department perform the necessary services and that the
department is in continuous efficient working service.
      2.   At a fire, the chief will have full charge of the matters pertaining
to the department and all things to be done in or about such fire, and he
shall, in case of necessity arising at a fire, employ, aside from his regular
force, so many men as may, in his judgment, be necessary for the purpose of
extinguishing the fire.
   B.   Reports: It shall be the duty of the chief of the fire department to
make out and submit annual reports to the mayor and council of the condition of
the department, and all matters of interest relating thereto. He shall also
report number of fires that have taken place during the past year, giving the
location of, date of, and other particulars of such fires. He shall incorporate
in said reports such suggestions in regard to the government of the fire
department and the efficiency thereof as may, in his judgment, seem proper and
necessary. After each fire, the chief shall make prompt and thorough
investigation of the cause of the fire, the amount of loss and insurance
carried, time of breaking out, description of building and all necessary
particulars and record the same in the record book kept for that purpose in the
department. (1974 Code § 1-604)
   C.   Authority To Prescribe Traffic Limits At Fire: Whenever a fire shall
occur in the city, the fire chief or acting fire chief is hereby empowered,
during the continuance of such fire, to prescribe the limits within which shall
be unlawful for any person to come, excepting members of said fire department,
the owners of the premises included in such limits, and such other persons as
may be specially admitted by the said chief or acting chief, and it shall be
the duty of such fire chief to plainly indicate such limits, either by
stretching a rope thereon or erecting some barrier sufficient to apprise the
people of such limits. And it shall be unlawful for any person other than the
above specified to enter within such limits at any time until same are removed.
(1974 Code § 1-607)
4-2-4: OFFICERS AND EMPLOYEES; DUTIES:
It shall be the duty of all officers and employees of the fire department to
attend to the duties of their respective positions under the orders of the
chief of the fire department, or in case of his absence or inability to serve,
under the assistant chief of the fire department. (1974 Code § 1-605)
4-2-5: POLICE; DUTIES AT FIRE:
It shall be the duty of the regular policemen of the City and those persons
designated at a fire as police officers by the Chief of the Fire Department to
see that the provisions of this chapter are complied with. (1974 Code § 1-606)
4-2-6: EQUIPMENT:
The equipment of the City Fire Department shall consist of the apparatus now
owned by the City, and that which may hereafter be purchased by the City and
all other things that are now used and have been used in connection with the
Fire Department. (1974 Code § 1-602)
4-2-7: LIMIT ON APPROACH TO FIRE:
Any person or persons not officers of the City, or acting firemen of the City,
or any person or persons not interested as owner or owners or employees of the
owner or owners, in the property and goods at the location of any fire who
shall occupy the grounds within fifty feet (50') of the fire, or impede the
work of the firemen, or blockade the way to, from or around any fire shall be
deemed guilty of an infraction. (Ord. 991, 10-11-2018)
4-2-8: DRIVING ACROSS HOSE OR INTERFERENCE WITH EQUIPMENT:
It shall be unlawful for any person within the City to ride or drive any horse
or vehicle of any kind over or across any water hose belonging to the City
while in use. And it shall be unlawful for any person other than the members of
the regularly organized fire company of the City, to handle or have in their
possession or in any manner interfere with any of the fire apparatus used by
the fire companies of the City, except at the express invitation or permission
of the Fire Chief or Acting Fire Chief of the City. (1974 Code § 1-609)
4-2-9: VIOLATION; PENALTY:
Any person guilty of violating any provision of this chapter shall be guilty of
an infraction and shall be punished, upon conviction thereof, as provided in
section
1-4-1 of this Code. (Ord. 991, 10-11-2018)
CHAPTER 3
GENERAL OFFENSES
SECTION:
4-3-1: Criminal Code Adopted
4-3-1: CRIMINAL CODE ADOPTED:
   A.   Adoption: There is hereby adopted by the city, Idaho Code title 18,
crimes and punishments, as presently in effect or as may hereafter be amended,
one copy of which is on file in the office of the city clerk-treasurer for
public inspection.
   B.   Penalty: Any person violating the provisions of this chapter, or the
statutes adopted herein, shall, upon conviction thereof, be subject to penalty
as provided in section
1-4-1 of this code. (2010 Code)
ARTICLE A. OFFENSES AGAINST MORALS, HEALTH AND POLICE
SECTION:
4-3A-1: Unlawful Consumption Of Or Possession Of Alcoholic Beverages In Public
Place
4-3A-1: UNLAWFUL CONSUMPTION OF OR POSSESSION OF ALCOHOLIC BEVERAGES IN PUBLIC
PLACE:
   A.   Definitions: As used in this section, the following words and phrases
shall have the meanings given herein when not inconsistent with the context.
Words used in the present tense include the future, words in the plural number
include the singular number, and words in the singular number include the
plural number. The word “shall” is always mandatory and not merely directory.
 
                    Any beverage containing alcohol that is a product of
ALCOHOLIC BEVERAGE: distillation of any fermented liquor, or synthetic ethyl
                    alcohol, including liquor, spirits, beer, wine or any
                    liquid containing liquor, spirts, beer or wine.
BEER:               Shall have the meaning it is given in title 3, chapter 2 of
                    this Code.
                    An area to which the general public has an unrestricted
                    right of access and that is generally open or used by the
                    public, regardless of whether it is publicly or privately
                    owned, Examples of public places include, without
PUBLIC PLACE:       limitation, streets, highways or public rights-of-way,
                    sidewalks, bridges, alleys, plazas, parks, public
                    driveways, parking lots, transit stations, trains, buses,
                    moving or stationary motor vehicles, shelters, tunnels, and
                    buildings, including, without limitation, stores and
                    restaurants.
 
WINE:               Shall have the meaning it is given in title 3, chapter 2 of
                    this Code.
 
   B.   Specified: Except as otherwise provided by license, permit or law, it
shall be unlawful for any person:
      1.   To consume any alcoholic beverage in a public place within the City;
or
      2.   To possess, in a public place within the City, any alcoholic
beverage in any bottle, can or other receptacle which has been opened, or has a
seal broken, or where the contents of which have been partially removed.
   C.   Exceptions: The provisions of this section shall not apply to the
possession or consumption of any alcoholic beverage by a person who is at least
twenty-one (21) years of age when such possession or consumption occurs:
      1.   Within any private residence or upon the yard thereabout, or within
any apartment, duplex, condominium, boarding house or other structure lawfully
used as a permanent residence, or within any common area or area designated
exclusively for and appurtenant to such residential occupancy;
      2.   Within an establishment, business place or other location properly
licenses and permitted by the State, the County and the City for the
consumption of any alcoholic beverage;
      3.   Pursuant to a valid City approved event which has been issued a City
catering permit or State approved permit; provided, that the alcoholic beverage
is held in an opaque plastic container.
(Ord. 1015, 11-14-2022)
ARTICLE B. OFFENSES AFFECTING PUBLIC SAFETY
SECTION:
4-3B-1: BB Guns And Air Guns
4-3B-2: Explosives
4-3B-3: Obstruction To Vision At Intersections
4-3B-4: Subterraneous Opening, Highway Or Sidewalk
4-3B-5: Tampering With Fire Equipment
4-3B-6: Throwing Stones Or Missiles
4-3B-7: Trespassing Upon City Property
4-3B-8: Violation; Penalty
4-3B-1: BB GUNS AND AIR GUNS:
   A.   Prohibited: It shall be unlawful for any person to fire or discharge
any cannon, gun, fowling piece, pistol or firearm, of any description, or
explode, or set off any combustible or explosive material within the city
unless such activity is: 1) allowed as fireworks under title 2, chapter 4 of
this code, or 2) when the firing of said arms is with blanks at a parade,
celebration, sporting event or theatrical performance, or 3) an activity which
is exempted or allowed under Idaho law as it now exists or is hereafter
amended.
   B.   Discharge Of BB Guns, Air Guns, Slingshots, Wrist Rockets And Bow And
Arrows Prohibited: The shooting or firing or discharging of any air rifle, air
pistol, air revolver, BB gun, slingshot, wrist rocket, or bow and arrow within
the limits of the city is hereby prohibited, unless: 1) such activity is
conducted at a firing range or at a competition which is sanctioned by a
sponsoring club or entity and is properly supervised; or 2) such activity is
conducted on private property with proper equipment to retain or keep the
projectile upon said private property; provided that when such activity is
conducted by a minor, the same shall be done under adult supervision.
   C.   Shooting Of Crossbows, Dart Guns Or Blowguns: The shooting of
crossbows, dart guns or blowguns within the limits of the city is prohibited.
(Ord. 984, 11-14-2016)
4-3B-2: EXPLOSIVES:
   A.   Prohibited; Exemption: It shall be unlawful to store or keep any
dynamite, nitroglycerin, giant powder, gunpowder, TNT, black powder, military
ordnance, C4 explosives, bombs, booby traps, bomb making materials or other
explosives within the city limits, unless the same is allowed under subsection
B of this section or a permit has been obtained in compliance with title 8,
chapter 3 of this code.
   B.   Storage Of Gunpowder Or Black Powder: The storing of gunpowder or black
powder under the following conditions is exempt from the prohibition set forth
in subsection A of this section:
      1.   Gunpowder: The storing of up to fifty (50) pounds of gunpowder for
personal reloading of shells, kept with reloading equipment and shell casings,
etc., to reload shells is exempt; however, a person keeping more than ten (10)
pounds of gunpowder shall register such fact with the city fire department for
the safety of city employees and volunteers.
      2.   Black Powder: The storing of up to ten (10) pounds of black powder
for personal use in firing of black powder rifles is exempt; however, a person
keeping more than five (5) pounds of black powder shall register such fact with
the city fire department for the safety of city employees and volunteers.
      3.   Registration Required: The registration with the city fire
department required in subsections B1 and B2 of this section shall also be
required whenever the total weight of both gunpowder and black powder at the
same premises equals ten (10) pounds.
   C.   Construction And Demolition Explosives:
      1.   License Required To Store Explosives: Any person, firm or
corporation intending to store explosives within the city limits to be used in
a demolition or construction project must obtain a written license from the
city to perform said demolition or construction work before bringing said
explosives into the city for storing.
      2.   Permit Required To Fire Explosives: Before firing such explosives,
the person or entity firing such explosives must obtain a written permit from
the city to fire or explode such explosives.
      3.   Licenses And Permits:
         a.   Forms: The written license and permit required by this section
shall be obtained from the city fire chief on forms supplied by the city.
         b.   Endorsement By Chief Of Police: Such license and permit shall be
endorsed by the chief of police.
         c.   Information And Data Given Strictly Followed; Changes: The
information and data given in obtaining the license and permit must be strictly
followed. Any changes in explosives, storing procedure, date of and time of
explosion will require an amendment to the license or permit affected by such
change.
         d.   Fees: The fee for said license and permit shall be set from time
to time by resolution of the city council. (1974 Code § 8-1201)
4-3B-3: OBSTRUCTION TO VISION AT INTERSECTIONS:
   A.   Obstruction Prohibited: No person shall plant, install, create,
maintain or possess, on public or private property, an obstruction to the
vision of a driver of a vehicle at an intersection which constitutes a traffic
hazard.
   B.   Prima Facie Evidence Of Obstruction: Prima facie evidence of an
obstruction constituting a traffic hazard shall exist if any object, structure
or thing, except buildings and residences which are otherwise in conformance
with the law, is allowed to exist which exceeds three feet (3') above the
existing roadway, centerline elevation within the triangular area formed by the
intersecting roadway edges and a straight line joining said roadway edges at
points which are forty feet (40') distance from the point of an intersection
measured along said street edges. At alley and street intersections, the
dimensions shall be forty feet (40') along the street edge and fifteen feet
(15') along the alleyway edge. Trees and utility facilities are allowed in such
triangular area provided that no tree limb or growth extending from said limb
shall be maintained or allowed to exist nearer than eight feet (8') from the
surface of the ground. (1974 Code § 8-1208)
4-3B-4: SUBTERRANEOUS OPENING, HIGHWAY OR SIDEWALK 1 :
   A.   Prohibited:
      1.   Leave Open Subterranean Opening: It shall be unlawful for any person
to leave or keep open any cellar, door, pit, vault, or other subterranean
opening in any highway or sidewalk; nor shall such person suffer the same to be
left open or kept in an insecure condition likely to be of danger to passersby.
      2.   Maintain Sidewalks In Good Repair: Provided further, that it shall
be unlawful for the owner or owners or occupants of premises abutting a
sidewalk to allow the same to become or remain so broken or otherwise out of
repair as to endanger life or limb or as to create a hazard to passing
pedestrians.
      3.   Keep Sidewalks Free And Clear Of All Debris, Snow, Ice Or Other
Substance: Provided, that this section further casts a duty upon the occupier,
owner or owners of premises abutting a sidewalk, to keep the same free and
clear of all debris, snow, ice or other substance or thing likely to create a
condition of danger to passing pedestrians.
   B.   Private Wells: All private wells located within the city, whether used,
unused, or abandoned, must be properly covered and sealed in such a manner so
as to prevent any unauthorized person or animal from removing said cover and in
such a manner that persons or animals not knowing the existence of said unused
well cannot fall into said well. Unused or abandoned wells must be covered or
capped with concrete or have a metal cap welded to the casing. Wooden well
covers on unused or abandoned wells are hereby prohibited within the city
limits.
   C.   Privies, Cisterns, Cesspools And Septic Tanks:
      1.   Cover Required: All privies, cisterns, cesspools and septic tanks
which are maintained and used within the city limits shall be covered in such a
manner that said covers will support a minimum weight of five hundred (500)
pounds without giving way or breaking.
      2.   Abandonment; Filling Required: Within thirty (30) days after any
privy, cistern, cesspool or septic tank is abandoned, or no longer used by the
property owner, said privy, cistern, cesspool or septic tank must be filled
level to the ground by said owner at said owner's expense, with earth, rocks
and/or stones so there is no hole for any person or animal to fall into.
   D.   Open Pits, Holes, Basements And Cellars: All open pits, holes,
basements and cellars located within the City limits must be either covered
with a roof or flooring which will support a minimum of five hundred (500)
pounds of weight per square foot, or by a six foot (6') high fence in such a
manner as to prevent unauthorized persons from entering the area so fenced in,
or be filled in with earth and/or rocks so that no pit, hole or cellar remains.
Provided, however, that this section shall not be operative during any period
of construction, unless said construction is suspended or abandoned for a
period of thirty (30) days or more, in which event it will apply.
   E.   Abandoned Underground Tanks: All underground tanks within the City
limits which are abandoned for a period of thirty (30) days must be removed
from the ground and the hole filled with earth so that no hole remains.
Provided, however, that any property owner may obtain, for just cause, a thirty
(30) day extension for compliance with this section from the City Fire Chief.
No one may be given more than five (5) consecutive thirty (30) day extensions.
   F.   Compliance Required: All of the provisions of this section must be
complied with by all property owners within the City. (1974 Code § 8-1205)
 
Notes
1 1. See also section
  6-2-10 of this code.
4-3B-5: TAMPERING WITH FIRE EQUIPMENT:
It shall be unlawful for any person, persons, corporation, or association of
persons, excepting the City officers and employees of City, and members of the
Fire Department of said City, to tamper with, open, close, or draw water from
any fireplug or tap, or hydrant belonging to said City, or any public hydrant
or tap whatever, or to tamper with any fire equipment, fire alarm system or
turn in any false alarm of a fire. (1974 Code § 8-1206)
4-3B-6: THROWING STONES OR MISSILES:
It shall be unlawful for any person to throw stones or other objects or
missiles upon or at any building or motor vehicle, whether occupied or
unoccupied, or at any tree, awning or other public or private property in a
manner likely to injure or deface such property, or injure any person. (1974
Code § 8-1204)
4-3B-7: TRESPASSING UPON CITY PROPERTY:
   A.   Sleeping, Occupying Or Trespassing Upon City Property: No person,
persons or groups of persons, other than employees, officers or agents of the
City shall occupy, sleep on, or trespass upon, any property under the control,
jurisdiction and ownership of the City between the hours of ten o'clock (10:00)
P.M. and six o'clock (6:00) A.M. unless they have first obtained a permit from
the Chief of Police. (1974 Code § 8-1001)
   B.   Permits: Permits allowing the above prohibited activities shall be
issued, without charge, by the Chief of Police upon request made to said Chief
of Police during the normal office hours of his office. Said permits shall be
issued in the name or names of all persons proposing to occupy, sleep in, or
trespass upon said City property, and if any be minors, then no permit shall
issue to them or their party unless and until it is shown that they are
accompanied by one or more of their parents, legally appointed guardian, or
coach or other mature and responsible person. Any person or persons aggrieved
by the Chief of Police denying a permit may appeal said decision to the Mayor
and City Council who will determine whether or not said permit shall be issued
at its next regularly scheduled meeting. (1974 Code § 8-1002)
4-3B-8: VIOLATION; PENALTY:
Every person convicted of violating subsection
4-3B-4A2 or A3 of this article shall be guilty of an infraction, and every
person convicted of violating any other provision of this article shall be
guilty of a misdemeanor, and shall be punished, upon conviction thereof, as
provided in section
1-4-1 of this Code. (Ord. 991, 10-11-2018)
ARTICLE C. OFFENSES AFFECTING PUBLIC PEACE AND QUIET
SECTION:
4-3C-1: Disorderly House
4-3C-2: Public Disturbance; Noise
4-3C-3: Violation; Penalty
4-3C-1: DISORDERLY HOUSE:
It shall be unlawful for any person to keep any common, ill governed or
disorderly house, nor shall suffer any drunkenness, quarreling, fighting or
riotous or disorderly conduct whatever on his or her premises. (1974 Code § 8-
1304)
4-3C-2: PUBLIC DISTURBANCE; NOISE:
It shall be unlawful for any person to cause, or for any person in possession
of property to allow to originate from the property, sound that is a public
disturbance noise. The following sounds are determined to be public disturbance
noises:
   A.   The frequent, repetitive, or continuous sounding of any horn or siren
attached to a motor vehicle, except as a warning of danger or as specifically
permitted or required by law.
   B.   The creation of frequent, repetitive, or continuous sounds in
connection with starting, operation, repair, rebuilding, or testing of any
motor vehicle, motorcycle, off highway vehicle, or internal combustion engine
within a residential district, so as to unreasonably disturb or interfere with
the peace, comfort, and repose of owners or possessors of real property.
Included shall be the use of motor vehicles with defective mufflers or without
mufflers.
   C.   The use of engine brakes on diesel trucks while operating within the
City limits for the purpose of braking, slowing or stopping. The term engine
brake shall include brakes commonly known as exhaust, jake, pac, or manifold
brakes.
   D.   The creation of frequent, repetitive or continuous sounds which emanate
from any building, structure, house, apartment, condominium, or person which
unreasonably interferes with the peace, comfort, and repose of owners or
possessors of real property, such as sounds from audio equipment, musical
instruments, band sessions, or social gatherings.
   E.   Sound from motor vehicle sound systems, such as tape players, radios,
and compact disc players, operated at a volume so as to be audible greater than
fifty feet (50') from the vehicle itself.
   F.   The foregoing provisions shall not apply to regularly scheduled and
City approved events at parks, streets, parking lots, or halls, such as public
address systems for games, concerts, rodeos or street dances. (1974 Code § 8-
1307)
4-3C-3: VIOLATION; PENALTY:
Any person guilty of violating any provision of this article shall be guilty of
an infraction and shall be punished, upon conviction thereof, as provided in
section
1-4-1 of this Code. (Ord. 991, 10-11-2018)
CHAPTER 4
MINORS
SECTION:
4-4-1: Purpose
4-4-2: Definitions
4-4-3: Truancy
4-4-4: Runaways And Incorrigibles
4-4-5: Curfew
4-4-6: Parental Responsibility
4-4-7: Enforcement Procedures
4-4-8: General Penalties And Treatment
4-4-1: PURPOSE:
The policy of the state and of the city is to:
   A.   Protect children's health and welfare, which includes their care,
guidance and control.
   B.   Parents, guardians, and/or other persons having legal custody are
responsible for providing for the physical custody and control of a child and
to determine where and with whom the child shall live and provide the child
with care, education and discipline.
   C.   A child who is unaccompanied by an adult having custodial rights, or an
adult person designated by a person having custodial rights, and who is found
to be on public streets, highways, roads, alleys, parks, playgrounds, or other
public grounds, places, vacant lots, or other locations unsupervised by such
adult, having the lawful authority to be at such place between the hours set
forth in this chapter is at greater risk for injury, becoming a victim of
crime, being involved in criminal activity, being a danger to persons or
property, or otherwise being subject to danger. (1974 Code § 8-401)
4-4-2: DEFINITIONS:
For the purposes of this chapter, the following terms, phrases, words and their
derivations shall have the meanings given herein. When not inconsistent with
the context, words used in the present tense include the future, words in the
plural number include the singular, and words in the singular number include
the plural. The word "shall" is always mandatory and not merely directory.
EMANCIPATED: Any person either eighteen (18) years of age or older, or if under
the age of eighteen (18), any person who is married or has been married; or any
person who is in active military service; or any person who is both self-
supporting and neither resides with nor is subject to parental control.
EMERGENCY: Includes any unforeseen health, accident, or crime related exigency
calling for immediate action.
JUVENILE AND MINOR: Any person less than the age of eighteen (18) and who has
not been duly emancipated.
MINOR: A person under eighteen (18) years of age.
PARENT: Any person having legal custody of a juvenile: a) as a natural or
adoptive parent, b) as a legal guardian, c) as a person who stands in loco
parentis, or d) as a person to whom legal custody has been given by order of
court.
REMAIN: To stay behind, to tarry and to stay unnecessarily upon the streets,
including the congregating of groups (or of interacting minors) totalling four
(4) or more persons in which any juvenile involved would not be using the
streets for ordinary or serious purposes such as mere passage or going home.
RUNAWAY: A juvenile under the age of eighteen (18) who has physically removed
himself from the supervision and control of his parents with the intent to
remain beyond the control of his parents.
TIME OF NIGHT: Referred to herein is based upon the prevailing standard of
time, whether Mountain Standard Time or Mountain Daylight Saving Time,
generally observed at that hour by the public in this jurisdiction.
YEARS OF AGE: Continues from one birthday, such as the sixteenth to (but not
including the day of) the next, such as the seventeenth birthday. (1974 Code §
8-402)
4-4-3: TRUANCY:
   A.   School Attendance Required: The parent or guardian of any child
resident in this state who has attained the age of seven (7) years at the time
of the commencement of school in his district, but not the age of sixteen (16)
years, shall cause the child to be instructed in subjects commonly and usually
taught in the public schools for the state of Idaho. Unless the child is
otherwise comparably instructed, the parent or guardian shall cause the child
to attend and said child shall attend a public, private or parochial school
during a period in each year equal to that in which the public schools are in
session; there to conform to the attendance policies and regulations
established by the board of trustees, or other governing body, operating the
school attended.
   B.   Exceptions: Any exceptions to this requirement as codified by any
school district or as contained in Idaho Code title 33, chapter 2, are hereby
recognized and given full force and effect. (1974 Code § 8-403)
4-4-4: RUNAWAYS AND INCORRIGIBLES:
It shall be unlawful for any person under the age of eighteen (18), living or
found in this jurisdiction to attempt to run away or to run away from his
parents, guardian or other legal custodian, or to be or remain a person who has
run away from his parents, guardian or other legal custodian, or who commits or
has committed any act or acts which render him incorrigible or places him
beyond the control of his parents, guardian or other legal custodian. (1974
Code § 8-404)
4-4-5: CURFEW:
   A.   Hours Of Curfew Imposed: It shall be unlawful for any person under the
age of eighteen (18) years to be or remain in or upon public property or
private property open to the public within this jurisdiction at night during
the period beginning at eleven fifty nine o'clock (11:59) P.M. and ending at
the following five o'clock (5:00) A.M.
   B.   Defenses: The following circumstances shall provide defenses to a
charge of curfew violation, and the juvenile shall have the burden of coming
forward with evidence of such circumstances at a hearing in order to raise
these defenses:
      1.   When accompanied by a parent or guardian of such juvenile.
      2.   When accompanied by an adult authorized by a parent of such minor.
      3.   When exercising first amendment rights protected by the United
States constitution, such as the free exercise of religion, freedom of speech,
and the right of assembly. The juvenile shall evidence the bona fides of such
exercise by first delivering to the chief law enforcement officer of this
jurisdiction a written communication, signed by the juvenile and countersigned,
if practicable, by a parent of the juvenile with their home address and
telephone number, specifying when, where and in what manner the juvenile will
be on the streets at night (during hours when the curfew ordinance is otherwise
applicable to said minor) in the exercise of a first amendment right specified
in such communication.
      4.   When the juvenile is on the sidewalk of a place where such juvenile
resides, or on the sidewalk of either next door neighbor not communicating an
objection to law enforcement.
      5.   When returning home, by a direct route from (and within 1 hour after
the termination of) a school or community sponsored activity, or an activity of
a religious or other voluntary association such as night classes, library
study, dances, proms, church socials, religious midnight masses or other late
night religious services, political activities including public hearings,
athletic events, concerts and cultural or contemporary music events.
      6.   When the juvenile provides a letter of employment, signed by at
least one parent and the juvenile's employer, renewable each calendar month
when the current facts so warrant, dated or reissued not more than forty five
(45) days previously, and briefly identifying the juvenile, the addresses of
his home and of his place of employment, and his hours of employment.
      7.   When the juvenile is, with parental consent, in a motor vehicle.
This contemplates normal travel. It is the intention of this provision to
clearly exempt bona fide interstate movement along major routes through this
jurisdiction and interstate travel beginning or ending in this jurisdiction.
      8.   In the event of an emergency.
      9.   Each of the foregoing exemptions, and their several limitations such
as provisions for notification, are severable, as provided in section
4-4-6 of this chapter but here reemphasized. These exceptions will be
reconsidered as warranted by future experience illuminated by the views of
student government associations, school personnel, citizens, associations,
parents, officers and persons in authority concerned positively with juveniles
as well as with juvenile delinquency. (1974 Code § 8-405)
4-4-6: PARENTAL RESPONSIBILITY:
   A.   Permit Or Allow Violation: It shall be unlawful for a parent having
legal custody of a juvenile knowingly to permit or by inefficient control to
allow the juvenile to violate any of the provisions of this chapter under
circumstances not constituting an exception to, or otherwise beyond the scope
of, this chapter. The term "knowingly" includes knowledge which a parent should
reasonably be expected to have concerning the whereabouts of a juvenile in that
parent's legal custody. It is intended to continue to keep neglectful or
careless parents up to a reasonable community standard of parental
responsibility through an objective test. It shall, therefore, be no defense
that a parent was completely indifferent to the activities or conduct or
whereabouts of such juvenile.
   B.   Presumption: If at any time within forty five (45) days following the
giving of notice as provided above, the minor to whom said notice related or
applied is again charged, and upon such charge is subsequently convicted of a
violation of the provisions of this chapter, it shall be rebuttably presumed
that the minor committed such subsequent violation with the knowledge,
allowance, permission or sufferance of the parent or guardian of such minor,
and said parent or guardian shall thereupon be charged with a violation of this
chapter. (1974 Code § 8-406)
4-4-7: ENFORCEMENT PROCEDURES:
   A.   Notice To Juvenile Of Violation: If a law enforcement officer
reasonably believes that a juvenile is in violation of any of the provisions of
this chapter, the officer shall notify the juvenile that he or she is in
violation of this chapter and shall require the juvenile to provide his or her
name, address and telephone number and how to contact his or her parent or
guardian.
   B.   Determination Of Age: In determining the age of the juvenile and in the
absence of convincing evidence such as a birth certificate, a law enforcement
officer on the street shall, in the first instance, use his or her best
judgment in determining age.
   C.   Normal Procedure: The normal procedure shall then be to take the
juvenile to said juvenile's home or the city police department, city hall,
where a parent or guardian shall immediately be notified to come for the
juvenile. Upon the arrival of the parent or guardian, the juvenile, parent and/
or guardian may be questioned as to relevant facts relating to the alleged
curfew violation so that this chapter may be informally and effectively
enforced. Such facts shall be accurately, fairly and impartially set forth in
the officer's report and will be made available to persons who have
responsibility for enforcement and treatment under this chapter. Constitutional
safeguards of the juveniles and the parent or guardian shall not be ignored.
   D.   Release To Custody Or Parent Or Other Responsible Adult: When a parent
or guardian has come to take charge of the juvenile and the appropriate
information has been recorded, the juvenile shall be released to the custody of
such parent or guardian. If the parent or guardian cannot be located or fails
to take charge of the juvenile, then the juvenile shall temporarily be
entrusted to an adult relative, neighbor or other person who will on behalf of
a parent or guardian assume the responsibility of caring for the juvenile
pending the availability or arrival of a parent or guardian.
   E.   Written Acknowledgment: Upon release of the juvenile to his or her
parent or guardian, the juvenile and parent or guardian shall sign a written
acknowledgment of the city curfew ordinance, which notice shall be presumptive
evidence of knowledge of this chapter.
   F.   Status Offenders: Status offenders shall not be placed in any jail
facility, but instead may be placed in juvenile shelter care facilities, except
in the case of runaways, when there is specific detention request from a
foreign jurisdiction to hold the child pending transportation arrangements.
(1974 Code § 8-407)
4-4-8: GENERAL PENALTIES AND TREATMENT:
   A.   Violation By Juvenile: Any juvenile who shall violate any of the
provisions of this chapter shall be guilty of a status offense punishable under
Idaho Code title 20, chapter 5, commonly known as the Juvenile Corrections Act.
(1974 Code § 8-408)
   B.   Violation By Parent Or Guardian: Any parent or guardian who shall
violate any of the provisions of this chapter, shall be guilty of an infraction
and, upon conviction, subject to penalty as provided in section
1-4-1 of this Code. Said parent or guardian may also be required to attend
class instructions on parenting provided through the Twin Falls County Juvenile
Probation Office. The purpose of the instruction is to provide the parents or
guardian with more ideas and support in raising their children. (Ord. 991, 10-
11-2018)
   C.   Preliminary Inquiry From Department Of Juvenile Probation: Upon a first
offense of any of the provisions of this chapter by the juvenile or parent, the
City Prosecuting Attorney may request a preliminary inquiry from the Department
of Juvenile Probation for screening and assessment according to the Department
of Juvenile Probation's designated and authorized procedures.
   D.   Two Status Offenses Within Twelve Months: Any child who has been
adjudicated for commission of two (2) status offenses within twelve (12) months
may be charged, petitioned and adjudicated as a habitual status offender for
the third status offense committed within that twelve (12) month period.
   E.   Expungement Of Record: Any proceedings hereunder for a status offense,
excluding habitual status offenses, shall be expunged when the minor reaches
the age of majority or is emancipated, upon application for expungement. (1974
Code § 8-408)
CHAPTER 5
ANIMAL CONTROL
SECTION:
4-5-1: Definitions
4-5-2: Dogs
4-5-3: Wild Animals
4-5-4: Vicious Animals
4-5-5: Running At Large
4-5-6: Animals In Public Buildings
4-5-7: Cruelty To Animals
4-5-8: Driving Or Riding Animals
4-5-9: Females In Heat
4-5-10: Nuisance
4-5-11: Enclosure For Breeding Animals
4-5-12: Liability For Damages Caused By Animal Owned By Minor
4-5-13: Kennels
4-5-14: Rabies, Disease And Quarantine
4-5-15: Impoundment
4-5-16: Payment Of Fees
4-5-17: Animal Traps
4-5-18: Uniform Citation; Prosecution
4-5-19: Administrative Procedure
4-5-20: Violation; Penalty
4-5-1: DEFINITIONS:
As used in this chapter, each of the terms defined shall have the meaning given
in this section unless a different meaning is clearly required by the context.
The word "shall" is mandatory, not directory.
ABUSE: Any case in which an animal has been the victim of intentional or
negligent conduct resulting in the animal's bruising, bleeding, malnutrition,
dehydration, burns, fractures or breaks of any bones, subdural hematoma, soft
tissue swelling, or death.
ANIMAL: Any organism other than human beings needing food to maintain and
sustain its life which generally has mobility and a developed central nervous
system.
ANIMAL CONTROL CONTRACTOR: The organization contracting with the city to
provide humane shelter services.
ANIMAL CONTROL OFFICER: The code enforcement officer and/or any city police
officer appointed by the city police chief to be primarily responsible for the
enforcement of this chapter. All members of the city police department shall
have the power to enforce this chapter.
AT LARGE: Off the premises of the owner, and not under the control of the owner
or a member of his immediate family either by leash, cord, chain or otherwise
provided for in this chapter. On the premises of the owner when the owner is
not at home and not under control by being within a home, enclosed yard or on a
leash or cord or chain.
BUILDING: Any structure with substantial walls and roof securely affixed to the
land and entirely separated on all sides from any other structure by space or
any walls in which there are no communicating doors, windows or openings, which
is designated or intended for the shelter, enclosure or protection of persons,
animals, chattels or property of any kind.
CITY: The city of Buhl, Idaho.
CITY CLERK-TREASURER: The clerk-treasurer of the city.
DOG: Shall be intended to mean both male and female, whether neutered or
spayed.
ENCLOSURE: A fence or structure of at least six feet (6') in height, forming or
causing containment suitable to prevent the entry of young children, and
suitable to confine an animal in conjunction with other measures which may be
taken by the owner such as tethering the animal. Such enclosure shall be
securely enclosed and locked and designed with secure sides, top and bottom and
shall be designed to prevent the animal from escaping from the enclosure. The
enclosure shall be constructed in such a manner as to prevent children from
reaching into the enclosure. The enclosure must have independent walls and be
set back a minimum of three feet (3') from any property line or any fence used
to enclose the owner's property.
HUMANE SHELTER: The humane shelter is established for the impounding and care
of animals seized, kept, or removed in conformity with the provisions of this
chapter, which humane shelter shall be under the jurisdiction of the city. The
city shall contract with a qualified entity for the purpose of maintaining and
operating the humane shelter and for the purpose of impounding, keeping and
disposing of any animal impounded according to the provisions of this chapter;
provided, that neither the contractor nor any employee employed by the
contractor shall be deemed to be city employees nor included within or under
the provisions of the civil service regulations.
IMPOUNDED: Taken into the custody of the humane shelter.
LEASH: A cord, chain or rope of the length to restrict the dog to the owner's
property or when the dog is off the owner's property, the leash shall not be
more than eight feet (8') in length unless the code specifically sets forth a
shorter or longer length.
MISUSE: The intentional causing of an animal to perform a noncustomary task
which could be dangerous or harmful to the animal.
NONCOMMERCIAL KENNEL/COMMERCIAL KENNEL: Any lot or premises or portion thereof
on which four (4) or more dogs, cats or any combination thereof (puppies or
kittens less than 3 months old do not count towards said limit), are
maintained, harbored, possessed, bred or cared for. A noncommercial kennel
exists when the animals are not owned primarily for resale. A commercial kennel
exits if the animals are owned for resale.
OWNER: Any person or persons keeping, harboring, possessing, caring for, or
having any custodial duties over any animal.
PERSON: Shall be intended to include all natural persons, firms, companies,
corporations or associations.
RUSH: The act of a dog in approaching a person in such a manner that the person
is put in fear that the dog is threatening or about to do such person bodily
harm and the dog has the apparent ability to do so.
SENIOR CITIZENS: Any head of household who has attained the age of sixty five
(65) years or older.
SIGN: Any structure which shall be used to attract attention to any object,
place, activity, person, animal, business which shall display or include any
letter, word, insignia, device or representation used as, or which is in the
nature of an announcement, direction or advertisement. The sign shall be
constructed of wood, metal or other similar weatherproof material, at least
twenty four inches by twenty four inches (24" x 24") in size, with letters in
indelible or fluorescent ink with the words in clear, capital letters as
follows: "VICIOUS ANIMAL ON PREMISES", "VICIOUS DOG ON PROPERTY", or words of
similar meaning; and shall be posted at all visible entryways onto the owner's
property.
VICIOUS ANIMAL:
   A.   Includes:
      1.   Any animal which, when unprovoked in a vicious or terrorizing
manner, approaches or rushes any person in apparent attitude of attack upon the
streets, sidewalks, any public grounds or places, or private property not owned
or possessed by the owner of the animal; or
      2.   Any animal with a known propensity, tendency or disposition to
attack unprovoked, to cause injury or to otherwise endanger the safety of human
beings or domestic animals; or
      3.   Any animal which bites, inflicts injury, assaults or otherwise
attacks a human being or domestic animal without provocation; or
      4.   Any animal owned or harbored primarily or in part for the purpose of
fighting or any animal trained for fighting; or
      5.   Any animal who fits the description of a vicious animal as set forth
in Idaho Code, section 25-2805(2) which is adopted herein by reference as if
set forth fully herein.
   B.   Does Not Include:
      1.   Notwithstanding the definition of a "vicious animal" in subsection A
of this definition, no animal may be declared vicious if an injury or damage is
sustained by a person who, at the time of such injury or damage was sustained,
was committing a wilful trespass or other tort upon the premises occupied by
the owner of the animal, or was teasing, tormenting, abusing or assaulting the
animal or was committing or attempting to commit a crime.
      2.   No animals may be declared vicious if the injury or damage was
sustained as a result of teasing, tormenting, abusing or assaulting the animal.
No animal may be declared vicious if the animal was protecting or defending a
human being within the immediate vicinity of the animal from an unjustified
attack or assault. (1974 Code § 8-101; amd. 2010 Code)
4-5-2: DOGS:
   A.   License And Registration:
      1.   Required: All dogs over the age of six (6) months, kept, harbored or
maintained by any person in the city shall be licensed and registered. (1974
Code § 8-117)
      2.   Issuance: Dog licenses shall be issued by the city clerk-treasurer
or any other person authorized by resolution of the city council to issue dog
licenses (upon payment of a license fee in the amount set by resolution of the
city council and approved by the mayor) for each dog. (1974 Code § 8-117; amd.
2010 Code)
      3.   Required Information: The owner shall state, at the time application
is made for such license, his name and address and the sex, breed and color of
each dog owned by him.
      4.   Term Of License; Renewal; Late Fee: All dog licenses shall expire on
December 31 of the year in which they are issued. All licenses purchased on or
after July 1 may be one-half (1/2) of the license fee if so provided in said
resolution and shall expire on December 31. The owner of any dog who fails to
register and license a dog within thirty (30) days after said license becomes
due shall pay a late licensing fee of an additional amount set by resolution of
the city council and approved by the mayor of the city over and above the
licensing fee.
      5.   Payment Of Fee: Payment of license fees shall be made to the city
clerk-treasurer or any person authorized to issue said license.
      6.   Applicability:
         a.   Vicious Animals: The provisions of this section and section
4-5-4, "Vicious Animals", of this chapter, shall apply to all vicious dogs that
a license or registration is applied for.
         b.   Nonresidents: The provisions of this section shall not be
intended to apply to dogs whose owners are nonresidents temporarily within the
city for thirty (30) days or less, nor to dogs brought into the city for the
purpose of participating in any dog show, nor to commercial kennels.
      7.   Assistance Dogs: Dogs used as guides for blind persons and commonly
known as "seeing eye" dogs and dogs trained as helpers of the handicapped shall
be licensed and registered as other dogs as provided in this section, except
that the owner or keeper of such dog shall not be required to pay any fee
therefor.
      8.   Spayed Female, Certificate Required: No female dog shall be licensed
as a spayed female except upon certification of a licensed veterinarian.
      9.   Rabies Vaccination: The owners of all dogs required to be licensed
under this chapter shall: a) provide their dog or dogs with a valid rabies shot
as hereafter provided, and b) present to the city clerk-treasurer, prior to
being issued a dog license, a valid rabies vaccination certificate issued by a
licensed veterinarian. In addition, any dog impounded within the city shall be
vaccinated for rabies, or proof thereof shall be provided by the owner prior to
release from the city pound. A rabies certificate shall be considered valid
within the following guidelines:
         a.   Within one year from the date of issue when the dog vaccinated
was less than one year old.
         b.   Within three (3) years from the date of issue when the dog
vaccinated was one or more years of age. (1974 Code § 8-117)
   B.   Exemptions: Any dog of either sex which has not reached the age of six
(6) months or any dog kept or maintained exclusively in a licensed kennel need
not be licensed. All other dogs, unless herein specifically exempted, are
required to be licensed. (1974 Code § 8-117; amd. 2010 Code)
   C.   Tag To Be Attached To Dogs; Certificate Retained By Owner: Upon payment
of the license fee, the city clerk-treasurer or any other person authorized by
resolution of the city council to receive license fees shall issue to the owner
a certificate and a tag for each dog so licensed. The shape or color of the tag
shall be changed every year, and shall have stamped thereon the year issued,
the words "Buhl Dog Tag" and the license number corresponding with the tag
number of the certificate. Every owner shall be required to provide each dog
with a collar or harness to which the license tag must be affixed, and shall
see that the collar and tag are constantly worn. Show dogs during showings are
exempt from wearing the collar and tag.
      1.   Duplicate Dog Tags: Duplicate dog tags shall be issued upon payment
of two dollars ($2.00) for each tag so issued to replace an original tag that
was lost or destroyed.
      2.   Dog Tags Not Transferable: Dog tags shall not be transferable from
one dog to another, and no refunds shall be made on any tag that was lost or
destroyed.
      3.   Inspection Of Certificate: The original certificate shall be
retained by the owner or harborer of the licensed dog for inspection by the
code enforcement officer or police department.
      4.   Unlawful To Remove: No person shall remove or cause to be removed
the collar or tag from any licensed dog without the consent of the owner,
keeper or harborer thereof.
      5.   Imitation License Tags: It shall be unlawful for any person to allow
any dog owned, kept or harbored to wear a license tag received on account of a
former licensee or to wear any imitation of the license tag issued by the city
for that year.
   D.   Training And Exercise Grounds: The council may designate such areas of
a public park or other public grounds of the city which may be used, subject to
the rules and regulations as may be prescribed, for the training or exercise of
dogs. Dogs within such area so designated need not be controlled by leash, but
shall be under the control of a responsible person and controlled by whistle,
voice, or other effective command. (1974 Code § 8-117)
4-5-3: WILD ANIMALS:
It shall be unlawful for any person to harbor, keep, maintain or possess, any
wild animal as determined by the chief of police and passed by resolution of
the city council. A listing of prohibited wild animals shall be kept at the
clerk-treasurer's office. (1974 Code § 8-106)
4-5-4: VICIOUS ANIMALS:
   A.   Registration:
      1.   Requirements For Registration: No vicious animal shall be licensed
by the city for any licensing period commencing after January 1, 2003, unless
the owner or keeper of such vicious animal shall meet the following
requirements:
         a.   Liability Insurance: The owner shall present to the city clerk-
treasurer or other licensing authority, proof that the owner or keeper has
procured liability insurance in the amount of no less than five hundred
thousand dollars ($500,000.00), covering any damage or injury which may be
caused by such vicious animal during the twelve (12) month period for which
licensing is sought, which policy shall contain a provision requiring the city
to be named as additional insured for the sole purpose of the city clerk-
treasurer or other licensing authority where such animal is licensed to be
notified by the insurance company of any cancellation, termination or
expiration of the liability insurance policy.
         b.   Tattoo:
            (1)   Definition: For the purposes of this section, "tattoo" shall
be defined as any permanent numbering of a vicious animal by means of indelible
or permanent ink with the number designated by the licensing authority, or any
other permanent, acceptable method of tattooing.
            (2)   Required: The owner shall, at his own expense, have the
licensing number assigned to such vicious animal, or such other identification
number as the city clerk-treasurer or other licensing authority shall
determine, tattooed upon such vicious animal by a licensed veterinarian or
person trained as a tattooist and authorized as such by any state, city or
police department. The tattoo shall be placed either on the upper inner lip,
inside ear or inside rear thigh of the vicious animal. The humane shelter may,
in its discretion, designate the particular location of said tattoo. Said
number shall be noted on the city licensing files for such vicious animal if it
is different from the license number of such vicious animal.
         c.   Warning Sign: The owner shall display a sign in conformance with
section
4-5-1 of this chapter on his or her premises warning that there is a vicious
animal on the premises. Said sign shall be visible and capable of being read
from the public highway.
         d.   Signed Statement: The owner shall sign a statement attesting
that:
            (1)   Insurance: The owner shall maintain and not voluntarily
cancel the liability insurance required by this section during the twelve (12)
month period for which licensing is sought, unless the owner shall cease to own
or keep the vicious animal prior to expiration of such license.
            (2)   Enclosure: The owner shall, on or prior to the effective date
of such license for which application is being made, have an enclosure for the
vicious animal on the property where the vicious animal will be kept or
maintained.
            (3)   Notice Required: The owner shall notify the licensing
authority and the animal control officer within twenty four (24) hours if a
vicious animal is on the loose, is unconfined, has attacked another animal or
has attacked a human being, or has died or has been sold or given away. If the
vicious animal has been sold or given away, the owner shall also provide the
licensing authority with the name, address and telephone number of the new
owner of the vicious animal.
      2.   Powers Of Animal Control Officer:
         a.   Make Inquiry; Seizure: The animal control officer is hereby
empowered to make whatever inquiry is deemed necessary to ensure compliance
with the provisions of this section, and any such animal control officer is
hereby empowered to seize and impound any vicious animal whose owner fails to
comply with the provisions hereof.
         b.   Failure To Surrender: In the event that the owner of the animal
refuses to surrender the animal to the animal control officer, the animal
control officer may request a police officer to obtain a search warrant from a
magistrate of the district court and to seize the animal upon execution of the
warrant. (1974 Code § 8-107)
   B.   Control Of Vicious Animal:
      1.   Locked Enclosure: All vicious animals shall be confined in an
"enclosure" as defined in section
4-5-1 of this chapter. It shall be unlawful for any owner to maintain a vicious
animal upon any premises which does not have a locked enclosure.
      2.   Requirements When Outside Dwelling Or Enclosure: It shall be
unlawful for any owner to allow any vicious animal to be outside of the
dwelling of the owner or outside of the enclosure unless it is necessary for
the owner to obtain veterinary care for the vicious animal or to sell or give
away the vicious animal or to comply with commands or directions of the animal
control officer with respect to the vicious animal, or to comply with the
provision of subsection A1a or A1b of this section. In such event, the vicious
animal shall be securely muzzled and restrained with a chain having a minimum
tensile strength of three hundred (300) pounds and not exceeding three feet
(3') in length, and shall be under the direct control and supervision of the
owner of the vicious animal.
      3.   Transfer Of Ownership: Upon the transfer of ownership of a vicious
dog, the dog shall remain classified as a vicious dog and the new owner must
comply with this chapter. The history of the vicious dog shall follow the dog
and apply to said dog regardless of any change of ownership. (1974 Code § 8-
108)
   C.   Animal Fighting; Attack:
      1.   Harboring Or Training Prohibited: No person shall own, harbor or
train any animal for the purpose of animal fighting, or train, torment, badger,
bait or use any animal for the purpose of causing or encouraging said animal to
unprovoked attacks upon human beings or domestic animals. (1974 Code § 8-109)
      2.   Commanding To Attack: Except where great bodily harm or death is
likely to immediately ensue, it shall be unlawful for any person to command,
encourage or aid by word or conduct, any animal to bite, chase, attack, or
attempt to bite, chase or attack another person or animal. (1974 Code § 8-103)
      3.   Sell, Breed Or Purchase Prohibited: No person shall possess with
intent or sell, or offer for sale, breed, or buy or attempt to buy any vicious
animal within the city. (1974 Code § 8-109)
   D.   Action For Damages; Destruction Of Offending Animal; Civil Penalty:
      1.   Damages: If any vicious animal shall, when unprovoked, kill or
wound, or assist in killing or wounding any sheep, lamb, cattle, horse, hog,
swine, fowl or other domestic animal, belonging to or in the possession of any
person, or shall, when unprovoked, attack, assault, bite or otherwise injure
any human being or assist in attacking, assaulting, biting or otherwise
injuring any human being while out of or within the enclosure of the owner or
keeper of such vicious animal, or while otherwise on or off the property of the
owner whether or not such vicious animal was on a leash and securely muzzled or
whether the vicious animal escaped without fault of the owner or keeper, the
owner or keeper of such animal shall be liable to the person aggrieved as
aforesaid, for all damage sustained, to be recovered in a civil action, with
costs of suit. It is reputably presumed as a matter of law that the owning,
keeping or harboring of a vicious animal in violation of this section is a
nuisance. It shall not be necessary, in order to sustain any such action, to
prove that the owner of such vicious animal knew that such vicious animal
possessed the propensity to cause such damage or that the vicious animal had a
vicious nature.
      2.   Destruction Of Animal: Upon such attack or assault, the animal
control officer in the city is hereby empowered to confiscate and destroy such
vicious animal, if the conduct of such vicious animal or its owner constituted
a violation of the provisions of this section, punishable by the confiscation
and destruction of the animal. (1974 Code § 8-110)
   E.   Exemptions:
      1.   Kennels: Subsections A through C, inclusive, of this section shall
not apply to kennels licensed in accordance with the provisions of this
chapter.
      2.   Police Department Or Law Enforcement: The provisions of this section
shall not apply to K-9 or other animals owned by any police department or any
law enforcement officer which are used in the performance of law enforcement
police work. (1974 Code § 8-111)
   F.   Penalties For Violation:
      1.   Violations: Any vicious animal:
         a.   Which does not have a valid license in accordance with the
provisions of this chapter; or
         b.   Whose owner does not secure the liability insurance coverage
required in accordance with subsection A of this section; or
         c.   Which is not maintained on property with an enclosure; or
         d.   Which shall be outside of either the dwelling of the owner, or an
enclosure except as provided in subsection B of this section; or
         e.   Which is not tattooed, (1974 Code § 8-112)
shall be confiscated by the animal control officer and destroyed in an
expeditious and humane manner after the expiration of a five (5) day waiting
period exclusive of Sundays and holidays. In addition, the owner, upon
conviction, shall be subject to penalty as provided in section
1-4-1 of this code.
      2.   Kill, Wound Or Worry Any Animal: If any vicious animal shall, when
unprovoked, kill, wound, or worry or assist in killing or wounding any animal
described in subsection D of this section, the owner of said animal shall, upon
conviction, be subject to penalty as provided in section
1-4-1 of this code, and the animal control officer is empowered to confiscate
and, after the expiration of a five (5) day waiting period exclusive of Sundays
and holidays, shall destroy said vicious animal. Each subsequent violation
shall be considered a separate offense. (1974 Code § 8-112; amd. 2010 Code)
      3.   Second Or Subsequent Violation: For a second or subsequent violation
of this section, the court may, in the interest of public safety, order the
owner to have the vicious animal destroyed or may direct the appropriate
authorities to destroy the animal. (1974 Code § 8-112)
      4.   Injure Or Kill Human Being: If any vicious animal shall, when
unprovoked, attack, assault, wound, bite or otherwise injure or kill a human
being, the owner shall, upon conviction, be subject to penalty as provided in
section
1-4-1 of this code. (1974 Code § 8-112; amd. 2010 Code)
      5.   Suspension Of Tattooing Requirement: No fine and/or tattooing
requirement shall be suspended by any court of competent jurisdiction. (1974
Code § 8-112)
   G.   Determination Of Vicious Animal:
      1.   Probable Cause:
         a.   Power To Convene Hearing: In the event that the animal control
officer or law enforcement officer has probable cause to believe that an animal
is vicious, the chief of police or his/her designee, shall be empowered to
convene a hearing for the purpose of determining whether or not the animal in
question should be declared vicious.
         b.   Investigation; Notice Of Hearing: The animal control officer or
chief of police shall conduct or cause to be conducted an investigation and
shall notify the owner of the animal that a hearing will be held, at which time
he or she may have the opportunity to present evidence why the animal should
not be declared vicious.
         c.   Hearing: The hearing shall be held promptly within no less than
five (5) nor more than ten (10) days after service of notice upon the owner of
the animal. The hearing shall be informal and shall be open to the public.
         d.   Determination; Notice: After the hearing, the chief of police or
his/her designated hearing officer, shall determine whether or not the dog is a
vicious dog and the owner of the animal shall be notified, in writing, of the
determination.
            (1)   Determined Vicious: If a determination is made that the
animal is vicious, the owner shall comply with the provisions of this section
in accordance with a time schedule established by the chief of police, but, in
no case, more than thirty (30) days subsequent to the date of the
determination.
            (2)   Determination Contested: If the owner of the animal contests
the determination, he or she may, within five (5) days of such determination,
bring a petition in the magistrate court in the fifth judicial district of the
state of Idaho, in and for the county of Twin Falls, wherein the animal is
owned, praying that the court conduct its own hearing on whether or not the
animal should be declared vicious. After service of notice upon the animal
control officer, the court shall conduct a hearing de novo and make its own
determination as to viciousness. Said hearing shall be conducted within
fourteen (14) days of the service of the notice upon the animal control officer
or law enforcement officer involved. The issue shall be decided upon the
preponderance of the evidence. If the court rules the animal to be vicious, the
court may establish a time schedule to ensure compliance with this section,
but, in no case, more than thirty (30) days subsequent to the date of the court
determination.
            (3)   Court Decision: The court may decide all issues for or
against the owner of the animal regardless of the fact that said owner fails to
appear at said hearing. The determination of the magistrate court shall be
final and conclusive upon all parties thereto. However, the animal control
officer or any law enforcement officer shall have the right to declare an
animal to be vicious for any subsequent actions of the animal.
            (4)   Seizure And Impoundment; Costs Of Impoundment: In the event
that the animal control officer or law enforcement officer has probable cause
to believe that the animal in question is vicious and may pose a threat of
serious harm to human beings or other domestic animals, the animal control
officer or law enforcement officer may seize and impound the animal pending the
aforesaid hearings. The owner of the animal shall be liable to the city for the
costs and expenses of impoundment of such animal.
      2.   Owner Believes No Violation:
         a.   Petition Court: If the owner of an animal impounded for an
alleged violation of subsections A through F of this section, inclusive, shall
believe that there shall not have been a violation of such subsections hereof,
such owner may petition the magistrate court of the fifth judicial district of
the state of Idaho, in and for the county of Twin Falls, praying that the
impounded animal not be destroyed.
         b.   Destruction Pending Owner's Petition: The impounded animal shall
not be destroyed pending resolution of such owner's petition if the petition
shall have been filed within five (5) days of impoundment of such animal and
notice shall have been served within five (5) days of the impoundment of such
animal upon the animal control officer or keeper of the impounded animal. The
hearing shall be conducted within fourteen (14) days from serving of this
notice.
         c.   Appeal To District Court: The decision of the magistrate court
may be appealed to the district court by any aggrieved party within forty two
(42) days of the decision. The animal shall remain impounded pending the
appeal.
         d.   Release Of Animal; Costs: If the court finds that there shall not
have been a violation of subsections A through F of this section, inclusive,
such animal may be released to the custody of the owner upon payment to the
humane shelter or animal control officer of the expense of keeping such animal.
The schedule of such costs as provided for by section
4-5-15 of this chapter shall be paid in full to the city clerk-treasurer before
the animal is released.
         e.   Violation By Owner: If the owner of the animal violates any of
the terms and conditions of subsections A1 through F of this section, said
owner shall be fined one hundred dollars ($100.00) for the first such violation
and two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) for each subsequent violation. (1974
Code § 8-114)
4-5-5: RUNNING AT LARGE:
Except as provided by subsection
4-5-2D of this chapter, any person who owns, harbors or has in his or her
control an animal, whether the animal is licensed or not, which animal is found
at large upon the streets or alleys of the city, or in any public place in the
city or upon any other premises without the consent of the person in possession
of such premises, is responsible for such animal being at large and is in
violation of this section; except:
   A.   When such animal is controlled by a leash not exceeding eight feet (8')
in length.
   B.   Such animal be confined in a motor vehicle. (1974 Code § 8-118)
4-5-6: ANIMALS IN PUBLIC BUILDINGS:
It shall be unlawful for any person to permit, allow, keep or carry any animal
in, upon or within a public transportation facility, or any other public
building or facility, particularly a building or facility in which food or
drink is prepared or stored, except that a disabled person shall not be denied
the use of any common carrier or public transportation facility or admittance
to any other public building or place within city limits by reason of his or
her being accompanied by a seeing eye or guide dog or dogs trained as helpers
of the handicapped specially trained for such purpose. It is the intent of this
section to permit and authorize a disabled person to have a seeing eye or guide
dog or helper dog with him or her in such places and while using such
facilities without being required to pay any additional charges for his or her
seeing eye or guide dog or helper dog, but such person shall be liable for any
damage or disturbance caused by such seeing eye or guide dog or helper dog.
(1974 Code § 8-119; amd. 2010 Code)
4-5-7: CRUELTY TO ANIMALS:
It shall be unlawful for any person to act in a cruel manner to any animal
within the city. The phrase "cruel manner" shall include, but is not limited
to, the following specific acts and omissions:
   A.   Failure To Provide: Any owner of an animal who fails to provide such
animal with:
      1.   Sufficient good and wholesome food; or
      2.   Proper shelter and protection from the weather; or
      3.   Proper veterinary care to prevent suffering or disease; or
      4.   A clean and wholesome environment in which to live; or
      5.   Protection from the abuse of other persons.
   B.   Prohibited Acts: Any person who, through act or omission, does any of
the following specific acts with an animal:
      1.   Abuses or otherwise mistreats; or
      2.   Tortures; or
      3.   Misuses; or
      4.   Overloads or overrides; or
      5.   Abandons; or
      6.   Trains or enters a dog or animal in a fight with another dog or
another animal or attending a fight between animals as a spectator or owner;
      7.   Exposes to unreasonable danger to health or life. (1974 Code § 8-
102)
   C.   Penalties: Any person violating any provision of this section shall be
deemed guilty of an infraction, and, upon conviction thereof, shall be subject
to penalty as provided in this Code. Each day such violation is committed or
permitted to continue shall constitute a separate offense. It shall be the duty
of any police officer, animal control officer, or other designated City
employee to take possession of any animal for which he has probable cause to
believe falls under the preceding section and deliver such animal to the humane
shelter. All costs incurred for the maintenance of such animal will be paid by
the person charged with the offense. (Ord. 991, 10-11-2018)
4-5-8: DRIVING OR RIDING ANIMALS:
No person shall lead, drive or ride any emu, llama, alpaca, pig, sheep, goat,
cattle or other animal over, across or upon any sidewalk, parkway or public
parking area, or over or across any public park except upon roadways, trails or
areas designated for such use. (1974 Code § 8-120; amd. 2010 Code)
4-5-9: FEMALES IN HEAT:
   A.   Penned Or Enclosed During Estrus: The owner of a female dog shall cause
such dog, when in season, to be penned or enclosed in such a manner as to
preclude other dogs from attacking such female dog or being attracted to such
female dog so as to create a public nuisance.
   B.   Allow To Stray Or Run At Large Prohibited: It shall be unlawful for the
owner or person having possession, charge, custody or control of any female dog
to cause, permit or allow the same to stray or run, or in any other manner to
be at large in or upon any street or sidewalk while such female dog is in the
copulating season.
   C.   Declared Nuisance: If a female dog cannot be controlled by owner during
the said copulating season, the female dog may be declared a nuisance and
impounded by the Code Enforcement Officer or Police Department. (1974 Code § 8-
131)
4-5-10: NUISANCE:
It shall be unlawful for any owner to fail to exercise proper care and control
of his animal to prevent it from becoming a public nuisance. Every person shall
be guilty of allowing an animal to become a nuisance when such animal:
   A.   Makes excessive, continuous or untimely barking, or noise;
   B.   Molests passersby, chases vehicles;
