collection, subject to the same penalties and to be collected and paid to the
city in the same manner as all other taxes. (1974 Code § 6-116; amd. 2010 Code)
6-2-10: TRAP DOORS, OPENINGS OR GRATINGS 1 :
   A.   Unlawful: It shall be unlawful to construct or maintain any trap door,
opening or grating in any public sidewalk in the city, except upon permission
therefor being granted by the city council by resolution being duly adopted.
(1974 Code § 6-117)
   B.   Openings In Sidewalks: Every person building, maintaining or permitting
any bulkhead, cellar or basement way, stairway, door, window, or other hole or
opening leading to or from the street or sidewalk to the premises owned or
occupied by him shall keep the same property guarded with a good substantial
rail, grate or other device, together with the manner of placing and
maintaining the same shall be approved by the building inspector, and the owner
or person having control of any premises to or from which such bulkhead,
cellar, or basement way, stairway, door, window, or other hole or opening shall
open or lead, and not protecting the same as aforesaid shall be guilty of
maintaining a nuisance, and, upon conviction thereof, shall be punished as
provided in section
6-2-12 of this chapter. (1974 Code § 6-118)
 
Notes
1 1. See also section 4-3B-4 of this code.
6-2-11: REMOVAL OF SNOW AND ICE:
   A.   Removal Required: Owners, tenants or occupants of any premises within
the city abutting or adjoining any public sidewalk shall remove all snow and
ice from any such sidewalk.
   B.   Notice To Remove: It shall be the duty of the city to notify any owner,
tenant or occupant of property herein described to remove or otherwise correct
the objectionable matter herein legislated against, which notice shall be sent
by registered mail to the last known address of such owner, tenant or occupant,
notifying him that he has a period of twenty four (24) hours from and after
receipt of such notice within which to correct or otherwise remove the snow and
ice. (1974 Code § 6-119)
6-2-12: VIOLATION; PENALTY:
   A.   Penalty: Any person violating any of the provisions of this chapter
including, but not limited to, the failure of the owner, tenant or occupant of
premises to comply with the terms and conditions of the notice or notices
provided for herein, shall, upon conviction, be subject to penalty as provided
in section
1-4-1 of this code. (1974 Code § 6-120; amd. 2010 Code)
CHAPTER 3
LIBRARY
SECTION:
6-3-1: Established
6-3-2: Board Of Directors
6-3-3: Use Free To Residents
6-3-1: ESTABLISHED:
A public library is hereby established in the city, located on parts of lots 8,
9 and 10 in block 98 in the Buhl townsite, under the provisions of Idaho Code
title 33, chapter 26, and that for such purpose the council of the city shall
annually levy and cause to be collected, as other taxes are, a tax as
determined from time to time by the city council on the taxable property of
said city, to constitute a library fund, which fund is hereby created, and
shall be kept by the city clerk-treasurer, separate and apart from other monies
of the city, and be used exclusively for personnel, the purchase of books,
periodicals, computers, necessary furniture and fixtures, building maintenance,
utilities, and whatever is required for the maintenance of such library. (1974
Code § 1-1001; amd. 2010 Code)
6-3-2: BOARD OF DIRECTORS:
   A.   Appointment: For the government of such library there shall be a board
of five (5) directors, all of whom shall be recommended and appointed by the
council from among the citizens thereof at large that reside in the city.
   B.   Term: Such directors shall hold their office for five (5) years from
the date of appointment and until their successors are appointed.
   C.   Vacancies: All vacancies shall be reported within five (5) days to the
city council by the board of directors and shall be filled by appointment in
the same manner as appointments are originally made. Appointments to complete
an unexpired term shall be for the residue of the term only.
   D.   Compensation: No compensation shall be paid or allowed to any directors
in any manner whatsoever. Prior approved expenses may be allowed. (1974 Code §
1-1002; amd. 2010 Code)
   E.   Organization:
      1.   Officers: The directors shall meet and organize by the election of
one of their number as president, and by the election of such other officers as
they may deem necessary every December at term renewal. (1974 Code § 1-1003;
amd. 2010 Code)
      2.   Bylaws, Rules And Regulations: The directors shall make and adopt
such bylaws, rules and regulations for their guidance and for the government of
the library as may be expedient.
      3.   Control Of Expenditures: The directors shall have the exclusive
control of the expenditures of all monies collected for the library fund.
      4.   Librarian: The directors may appoint a librarian and assistants, and
prescribe rules for their conduct. (1974 Code § 1-1003)
   F.   Report To Idaho Commission For Libraries: The board of directors shall
make an annual itemized report to the Idaho commission for libraries, formerly
the Idaho state library, on or before January 1 of each year, stating the
condition of their trust, and the various sums of money received from the
library fund and from all sources, and how much had been expended, the number
of books and periodicals on hand, and the number added by purchase, gift or
otherwise, during the year, the number lost or removed, the number of books
loaned out, and other statistics required by the Idaho commission for
libraries. (1974 Code § 1-1005; amd. 2010 Code)
   G.   Authority To Accept Donations: The library board is hereby authorized
to accept donations of money, personal property or real estate for the benefit
of such library. Title to such property shall be vested in said board of
directors to be held in control by said board, when accepted according to the
terms of the deed of gifts, devise or bequest of such property said board shall
be held and considered to be the special trustees. (1974 Code § 1-1006)
6-3-3: USE FREE TO RESIDENTS:
The library established under this chapter shall be forever free for the use of
the residents of the city, subject to such reasonable rules and regulations as
the library board may find necessary to adopt and have available for public
inspection in order to render the use of the library of the greatest benefit to
the greatest number, and they may exclude and cut off from use of said library
any and all persons who shall wilfully violate such rules. (1974 Code § 1-1004;
amd. 2010 Code)

00°29'13" West along the West line of said Section 34 for 332.27 feet to the
true point of beginning; thence North 89°56'13" East for 331.09 feet; thence
South 00°28'05" West for 664.64 feet; thence South 89°57'18" West for 331.31
feet to the West line of said Section 34; thence North 00°29'13" East along
said West line for 664.53 feet to the true point of beginning. Containing 5.05
acres more or less.
(1974 Code § 9-101)
6-4-2: AIRPORT COMMISSION:
   A.   Established: There is hereby established an airport commission,
consisting of five (5) persons who shall look after the airport and make
recommendations to the city council as to rules and laws necessary for its
operation.
   B.   Membership:
      1.   Appointment: The five (5) members shall be appointed by the mayor
and approved by the city council at the first council meeting of each year from
a list of nominees provided by the existing airport commission.
      2.   Term: These five (5) members shall each serve three (3) year terms.
The mayor shall inform the current commissioners of their terms so that the
rotating three (3) year terms will become effective immediately.
   C.   Youth Member:
      1.   Appointment: In addition to the members provided for above, the city
mayor, with the approval of the city council, may appoint one "ex officio"
youth member under twenty one (21) years of age. The youth member shall
participate in all discussions, but will not have a vote.
      2.   Term: The youth member's term shall be one year, from October 1 to
September 30 of the following year, and may be reappointed up to four (4)
successive terms. In computing the number of terms one can serve, the
completion of less than one-half (1/2) of the term of a previous youth member
shall not be counted as a term.
   D.   Duties: This commission shall recommend matters of policy to the city
council, and if the council shall approve them the commission shall see that
they are carried into force and effect. (1974 Code § 9-104; amd. Ord. 1004, 8-
9-2021)
6-4-3: OPERATION OF AIRPORT:
The mayor and city council of the city are hereby authorized to comply with all
requirements of the civil aeronautics administration in connection with said
airport and they are further authorized to promulgate such rules and
regulations relative to the management of said airport and such further rules
as they deem necessary in connection with the operation of the said airport and
the personnel thereon. (1974 Code § 9-103)
6-4-4: PROCEDURE, RULES AND REGULATIONS:
The procedure, rules and regulations governing and regulating the use,
maintenance and guarding of the Buhl municipal airport shall be such procedure,
rules and regulations as may now be prescribed, and as may from time to time
hereafter be prescribed, by the civil aeronautics administration of the
department of commerce of the United States, touching and concerning airports
of the class and designation as the said airport is classed and designated by
said administration, which applicable procedure, rules and regulations as are
now in force and effect and all the same amendatory thereof or supplementary
thereto, are hereby adopted. (1974 Code § 9-102)
6-4-5: CONSTRUCTION OF HANGARS; RENTAL SPACE:
   A.   Specifications: All hangars that are placed on the airport shall be
constructed upon a substantial cement or cinder block foundation or similar
material; each hangar shall be of good substantial construction and shall be
fireproofed. Each hangar shall be kept in a good state of repair so as to at
all times be an asset to said airport and sightly in appearance; each hangar
must be painted with an adequate number of coats of high grade asphalt aluminum
paint necessary to maintain its good appearance.
   B.   Doors: Each hangar shall be equipped with doors of sturdy construction
that will at all times hang straight, and said doors shall be closed at all
times except when taking an airplane in or out of the hangar.
   C.   Lease Required: A lease will be given to anyone desiring to place a
hangar on the airport, and the owner of the hangar must abide by the terms of
this lease or forfeit his right to have a hangar on said field. (1974 Code § 9-
106)
   D.   City To Have Lien: The city shall have a lien on any aircraft and
attendant property, including buildings, parts and equipment, placed on the
airport premises from the date hereof, for any unpaid charges until same are
fully satisfied and the city may retain possession of said aircraft and
attendant property, including buildings, parts and equipment placed on the
airport premises, and sell the same at public auction, after giving ten (10)
days' public notice of sale by advertising in the official newspaper. The
proceeds of the sale must be applied to the discharge of the lien and costs;
the remainder, if any, must be paid over to the owner. (1974 Code § 9-106; amd.
2010 Code)
6-4-6: BUILDING SPECIFICATIONS:
All building specifications are to be approved by the airport commission. After
this approval is obtained a permit must be obtained from the city to build.
(1974 Code § 9-105)
6-4-7: ZONING DISTRICT 1 :
Those lands, the boundaries of which are described in section
6-4-1 of this chapter, shall, for zoning purposes, be placed within the airport
district. The official zoning map as established pursuant to title 9, chapter 6
of this code shall designate those lands as coming within the airport district.
The boundaries of the airport district, for zoning purposes, may be enlarged or
restricted as provided by the general provisions of the city zoning ordinance
as found at title 9 of this code. As concerns the airport district, the same is
herein established for zoning purposes, the following provisions shall apply:
   A.   Intent: It is intended that all lands within the airport zone or
district shall be primarily available for municipal airport purposes. Excepting
other nonconforming uses or buildings now conducted or located on the property
within the airport district, all such land shall be used or occupied and any
building, structure or improvement thereon shall only be used, occupied,
placed, replaced, erected, reerected, constructed, reconstructed, altered,
extended, enlarged, modified, removed or moved upon obtaining from the planning
and zoning commission for the city a special use permit.
   B.   Zoning Applicable: Except as modified herein, all provisions of title 9
of this code shall apply to those lands located within the airport zoning
district.
   C.   Administration: The administration of title 9 of this code as well as
the provisions herein as concerns those lands located within the airport zoning
district, shall be vested with the planning and zoning commission of the city.
(1974 Code § 9-108)
 
Notes
1 1. See subsection
  9-6-1F of this code.
6-4-8: VIOLATION; PENALTY:
Any person, firm or corporation violating any provisions of this chapter or of
the rules and regulations of the civil aeronautics administration of the
department of commerce of the United States which is herein adopted, shall be
guilty of a misdemeanor and, upon conviction thereof, shall be subject to
penalty as provided in section
1-4-1 of this code. (1974 Code § 9-107; amd. 2010 Code)
CHAPTER 5
PARKS AND RECREATIONAL AREAS
SECTION:
6-5-1: Supervision; Rules And Regulations
6-5-2: City Parks
6-5-3: Skatepark
6-5-4: Violation; Penalty
6-5-1: SUPERVISION; RULES AND REGULATIONS:
All parks and recreational areas operated and maintained by the city shall be
under the supervision of the mayor and council, or their duly designated agent
or agents. The mayor and council shall, by resolution or ordinance, from time
to time, promulgate rules and regulations for the operation and maintenance of
such areas, and shall have the authority to establish schedules of fees to be
charged for the use of the same. (1974 Code § 10-101)
6-5-2: CITY PARKS:
City parks which have been named are as follows:
   A.   Jess O. Eastman Park: City park bounded by Maple Street, 6th Avenue,
Poplar Street, and 8th Avenue.
   B.   Dr. A.F. McClusky Park: Lot 2 of Inventors 4th addition adjacent to
Poplar Street.
      1.   The Alta Gannon Stage at McClusky Park. (1974 Code § 10-102)
      2.   The Buhl Centennial Skatepark at McClusky Park. (2010 Code)
   C.   Faris Field: Athletic field and lot 13 of Rodanbaugh addition, bounded
by Linden Street, 13th Avenue, and Birch Street 1 .
      1.   Clint Faux Diamond: At Faris Field, northeast baseball diamond.
      2.   Carey Schmeckpeper Diamond: At Faris Field, southwest baseball
diamond.
   D.   North Park: Athletic field adjacent to east side of Sawtooth Boulevard.
      1.   Kris Nungester Field: At North Park, west baseball diamond.
      2.   J.P. "Pat" Hamilton Field: At North Park, east baseball diamond.
      3.   Bobby Diercksen Field: At North Park, the north baseball diamond/
soccer field adjacent to Sawtooth Boulevard and Clear Lakes Road.
      4.   Community Field: At North Park, the south baseball diamond/soccer
field adjacent to Bobby Diercksen Field and Clear Lakes Road.
   E.   John Barker Memorial Park: Located in lot 2 of section 1, T10S, R 14
EBM near the Grove Subdivision 2 . (1974 Code § 10-102)
   F.   Rotary Triangle Park: Located on the east side of Main Street at the
intersection of Main Street and Clear Lakes Road.
   G.   Rotary Centennial Park: Located on the south side of Sawtooth Boulevard
at the intersection of Sawtooth Boulevard and Broadway Avenue.
   H.   Chamber Park: Located on the north side of U.S. Highway 30 at 716 U.S.
Highway 30 E.
   I.   John B. Crawford Park: Located on the south side of Clear Creek Drive
at the intersection of Clear Creek Drive and Milner Street.
   J.   Buhl Centennial Skatepark: Located within Dr. A.F. McClusky Park. (Ord.
962, 8-13-2012)
 
Notes
1 1. Deeded to the city by Buhl School District, Ord. 568, 5-1-1973; and deeded
  to city by Buhl Recreation Association, Inc.
2 1. Named in deed to city dated 3-12-1996.
6-5-3: SKATEPARK:
   A.   Rules: The following rules shall apply to anyone and everyone using the
Buhl Centennial Skatepark at Dr. A.F. McClusky Park:
      1.   The park closes at ten o'clock (10:00) P.M. and thirty (30) minutes
before and thirty (30) minutes after any stage production, if asked to do so by
the sponsor of the stage production.
      2.   The park is unsupervised. Skate at your own risk.
      3.   Helmets are required for ages eighteen (18) and under. Protective
gear (helmets, knee and elbow pads) is recommended.
      4.   No bicycles, scooters or motorized vehicles allowed. The park is
designated for skateboards, in-line and roller skates only.
      5.   Skate within your ability and control, with the traffic flow.
      6.   Be respectful of others. The skaters' code of ethics is something to
be proud of.
      7.   Take pride in your park and use trash containers. Skaters trash
their boards, not their park.
      8.   All alcohol, tobacco, and drugs are prohibited in this park.
      9.   Vandalism, graffiti and tagging is prohibited. (1974 Code § 10-104)
   B.   Parent's Notification Of Violation: The parent(s) or guardian(s) of any
person under eighteen (18) years of age shall be informed in person or by
letter of any violation of the rules set forth in subsection A of this section
by such minor. (1974 Code § 10-105)
   C.   Warning: In lieu of the penalty for failure to observe rules and
regulations set out in subsection A of this section, any violators of these
rules may be issued a warning and suspended from using the skatepark for a
period of up to thirty (30) days. Should said violators not comply with the
suspension or repeat the violation, the penalty of section
6-5-4 of this chapter may be applied. (1974 Code § 10-106)
6-5-4: VIOLATION; PENALTY:
Any person, firm or corporation who refuses or fails to observe any of the
provisions of the rules and regulations or fee schedules as provided for in
section
6-5-1 of this chapter, shall be guilty of an infraction and shall also be
subject to suit by the City for all damage to City property and be liable for
City Attorney fees and costs of bringing such civil action. (Ord. 991, 10-11-
2018)
ARTICLE A. PARKS AND TREE COMMITTEE
SECTION:
6-5A-1: Composition
6-5A-2: Responsibility
6-5A-3: Officers; Meetings
6-5A-4: Coordination And Communication
6-5A-5: Funding
6-5A-1: COMPOSITION:
   A.   Membership: A committee of five (5) individuals, three (3) of which
must reside within the city limits and two (2) of which may reside outside the
city limits shall be appointed by the mayor with the approval of the city
council to serve until the term of the mayor who appoints the committee members
expires.
   B.   Council Liaison: A city council member shall be appointed to serve as
council liaison.
   C.   Ex Officio Members: The city public works director and parks
superintendent shall be ex officio members of the committee.
   D.   Youth Member: In addition to the members provided for above, the city
mayor, with the approval of the city council, may appoint one ex officio youth
member under twenty one (21) years of age, who lives within the city or its
impact area. The youth member shall participate in all discussions, but will
not have a vote. The youth member's term shall be one year, from October 1 to
September 30 of the following year and may be reappointed up to four (4)
successive terms. In computing the number of terms one can serve, the
completion of less than one-half (1/2) of the term of a previous youth member
shall not be counted as a term. (1974 Code § 10-201)
6-5A-2: RESPONSIBILITY:
   A.   Advisory In Nature: The committee shall be advisory in nature with the
purpose of providing advice to the mayor and city council as to the
preservation, protection and management of the community parks and forest, in
accordance with the intent and purpose of this title.
   B.   Findings And Recommendations: The committee will report its findings
and recommendations to the mayor and city council as requested by the mayor and
city council, or as is appropriate.
   C.   Hear Appeals:
      1.   License And/Or Certification Applicants: The committee will hear
appeals from license and/or certification applicants who are aggrieved of some
actions or omissions taking place pursuant to the license/certification
procedures of this title.
      2.   Controllers And/Or Licensees: The committee will hear appeals from
controllers and/or licensees who are aggrieved by the granting or denial of a
permit required by this title.
   D.   Community Forestry Issues: The committee will help develop and
implement educational materials and programs addressing community forestry
issues.
   E.   Recommend Needs To Maintain: The committee will make recommendations to
the council annually regarding needs of the several parks to maintain the
trees, grass, vegetation, and facilities of the several park areas for their
use by the public.
   F.   Permanent Changes: The committee will review and make appropriate
recommendations regarding all trees, shrubs, flowers and permanent changes to
the several parks such as erecting monuments, shelters, or other proposals as
may come before the council. To require scaled plans or drawings of proposed
projects when the committee feels such are necessary for making said
recommendation.
   G.   Guidelines For Use: The committee will propose guidelines for the use
of the parks by the public.
   H.   Disagreement With Committee Recommendations: Any organization or person
who does not agree with the committee recommendations may ask the city council
for time to submit their proposal as they desire it. The committee shall be
allowed time to submit to the council its opinion and recommendation on such
proposal.
   I.   Day To Day Operation And Maintenance: The day to day operation and
maintenance of the parks is and shall be done by the public works department of
the city. (1974 Code § 10-202)
6-5A-3: OFFICERS; MEETINGS:
The committee shall elect a president and vice president from within its
membership and a secretary-treasurer, shall hold regular meetings as required
by the president, and shall cause the secretary to maintain a written record of
its deliberations and proceedings. (1974 Code § 10-203)
6-5A-4: COORDINATION AND COMMUNICATION:
The committee will coordinate its activities regarding public trees in public
parks by communicating with the public works department, the parks
superintendent and forester. (1974 Code § 10-204)
6-5A-5: FUNDING:
The committee shall recommend an annual budget to the mayor and city council.
The committee is authorized to seek outside funding for committee projects as
may be approved by the city council in accordance with city budgetary
procedures. (1974 Code § 10-205)
CHAPTER 6
TREES AND SHRUBBERY
SECTION:
6-6-1: Definitions
6-6-2: Forester
6-6-3: Permits To Plant
6-6-4: Trees Permitted; Spacing
6-6-5: Permits For Removal
6-6-6: Dead Or Diseased Trees
6-6-7: Shade Trees; Damaging, Destroying
6-6-8: Pruning
6-6-9: Injurious Pests; Failure To Prune
6-6-10: Duties Of Owners
6-6-11: Work Done By City; Discretion Of City Parks And Tree Committee
6-6-12: Trees Grown In Containers On Streets
6-6-13: Violation; Penalty
6-6-1: DEFINITIONS:
For the purpose of this chapter the following words shall have the following
meanings:
PARKWAY: That portion of public right of way situated between the curb line of
any street and the property line of property abutting and adjoining any street.
In the absence of a curb, the curb line of a street shall be deemed to be the
edge of that portion of public right of way maintained and open to the use of
the public for purposes of vehicular travel.
PERSON: Any person, firm, partnership, corporation, association, company or
organization of any kind.
STREET: Highways, roads, alleys and bridges dedicated, purchased or otherwise
acquired for the public, including the unimproved or unused portion thereof,
maintained and open to use by the public, including sidewalks, parkways and
special tree planting easements adjacent to a street granted by property
owners.
TREES: All trees, plants and shrubs which, upon maturity, grow to a height of
more than three feet (3'). (1974 Code § 10-301)
6-6-2: FORESTER:
   A.   Appointment: The forester shall be appointed by the mayor with the
advice and consent of the council, and shall have such duties and perform such
functions as shall be prescribed in this chapter and as required by the rules
and regulations of the mayor and council and the city parks and tree committee.
(1974 Code § 10-302)
   B.   Budget: Each fiscal year, the budget of the forester shall be contained
in, but as a separate item of, the budget of the department of parks. (1974
Code § 10-303)
   C.   Directives; Authority: For the purpose of prohibiting the planting and
growing of the types or kinds of trees that may be hazardous, susceptible to
disease and insects, or injurious to sidewalks and curbs, and for the further
purpose of providing an aesthetically attractive plan of planting and growth of
trees for the beautification of the streets of the city, and to that end to
control and regulate the types or kind of trees permitted to be planted in, or
overhanging any street, the forester, subject to the provisions of this
chapter, is hereby authorized and directed to:
      1.   Plant, prune, spray, preserve and remove trees in public places to
ensure safety or preserve symmetry and beauty of such public places.
      2.   Order the pruning, preservation or removal of trees upon private
property when the forester or the city parks and tree committee shall find such
action necessary for public safety or to prevent the spread of disease or
insects to public trees and places.
      3.   Supervise all work done under a permit issued in accordance with the
terms of this chapter.
      4.   Divide the city into zones, districts or areas, and to specify the
type or kind of trees which may hereafter be planted and maintained in or over
any street within any such zone, district or area.
      5.   Provide for the spacing of, or distance permitted between, all such
trees.
      6.   Provide for the form of application for removal, or the planting, of
any such tree.
      7.   Establish and maintain a nursery for the growing of the types and
kinds of trees permitted, and to sell and plant the same, upon the payment of
the fees provided for in this chapter. (1974 Code § 10-304)
   D.   Map Or Plat:
      1.   Preparation: To carry out the purposes, functions and duties
prescribed by subsection C of this section, the forester shall cause to be
prepared a map or plat showing the zones, districts or areas of the city, and
the types or kinds of trees permitted within each zone, district or area.
      2.   Copies On File: Copies of such map or plat shall be kept on file in
the offices of the forester and the city clerk-treasurer, and shall be open to
public inspection. (1974 Code § 10-305)
6-6-3: PERMITS TO PLANT:
   A.   Permit Required: It shall be unlawful for any person to plant any tree
in or within five feet (5') of any street, except and until a permit shall have
been issued therefor by the forester. Applications for tree planting shall be
filed with the forester, or with the city clerk-treasurer for transmittal to
the forester.
   B.   Applicant To Furnish Trees; Approval Required: If the applicant himself
desires to furnish a tree for planting, he shall so specify in his application
together with the name of the nursery, if any, to furnish and plant the same.
Such trees must be of the type and variety permitted under subsection
6-6-2C of this chapter and before planting must be approved by the forester for
size, variety and freedom from disease. (1974 Code § 10-306)
   C.   Amendment Of Application: All applications for tree planting permits
may be amended at any time so as to conform to the provisions of this chapter.
   D.   Denial Of Application: If any application is denied by the forester,
the application shall be returned to the applicant with the reasons for the
refusal noted thereon.
   E.   New Or Amended Application: The applicant may file a new application,
with the refusal noted thereon, or an amended application at any time
thereafter. (1974 Code § 10-307)
6-6-4: TREES PERMITTED; SPACING:
   A.   Type, Kind And Variety; Location: Each permit issued for tree planting
shall designate the type, kind and variety of tree permitted, and the forester
shall designate the location therefor.
   B.   Approved Street Tree List:
      1.   Annual Review And Update: Approved species, species not permitted,
authorized spacing information and minimum tree well sizes for trees planted in
paved areas shall be obtained from the approved street tree list for the city,
which shall be reviewed and updated annually by the forester.
      2.   Variance: Permission for variance of the approved list may be
granted by the forester, if, in the judgment of the forester, said variance
will be beneficial to the city.
   C.   Distance From Sidewalk Line: No person shall plant any tree within two
feet (2') of the established sidewalk line; provided, that the provisions of
this subsection may be varied in special cases upon the approval of the
forester. (1974 Code § 10-308)
6-6-5: PERMITS FOR REMOVAL:
   A.   Permit:
      1.   Required: Except as provided by section
6-6-6 of this chapter, it shall be unlawful for any person to remove any tree
from any street until a permit shall have first been issued by the forester.
      2.   Application; Issuance: Applications for such tree removal shall be
filed with the forester, and if, in the judgment of the forester, such removal
is desirable, a permit shall be issued.
      3.   Removal Supervised: All work of removal shall be under the
supervision of the forester.
      4.   Permit Fee: No fee shall be charged for a removal permit. (1974 Code
§ 10-309)
      5.   Owner Requests Removal By City; Cost: In cases where the owner
requests such removal by the city, a fee shall be established and collected by
the forester of not less than one hundred fifty dollars ($150.00) up to actual
cost for each tree to be removed. All trees so removed by the city shall
thereupon be the property of the city. (1974 Code § 10-309; amd. 2010 Code)
   B.   Replacement:
      1.   When Required: Whenever, in the opinion of the forester, any tree
removed under the provisions of this section should be replaced, it shall be a
condition and a part of the permit for removal that the permittee plant, or
permit the planting of, the type of tree or trees and at the location specified
by the forester.
      2.   Fees:
         a.   Trees Furnished Or Planted By City: All fees for trees to be
furnished and/or planted by the city are payable at the time of planting. In
the event that said fees become delinquent they are hereby declared to be a
lien upon the adjacent real property owned by such person or persons where the
trees or trees were planted. (1974 Code § 10-309)
         b.   Furnished By Outside Source; Deposit: Any property owner desiring
to replace removed trees from an outside source must file a deposit of twenty
five dollars ($25.00) per tree to be replaced with the forester and shall have
one year's time from the completed removal date to replace said trees. At the
end of the specified time period, if the trees have not been replaced by the
owner, the forester is hereby directed to replant the number, size, and kind of
trees he deems necessary and shall use said deposit monies as partial payment
thereof and the owner will be billed for remainder of the actual cost. If the
owner properly replaces the trees as agreed, the deposit will be refunded to
the owner. (1974 Code § 10-309; amd. 2010 Code)
   C.   Fees For Removal Caused By Establishment And Creation Of Local
Improvement District: The fee or cost for removal of a tree or trees caused by
the establishment and creation of a local improvement district shall be
included as part of the costs and expenses of improvements authorized and
ordered by a local improvement district and shall be assessed against the
abutting, adjoining, contiguous and adjacent lots and lands benefited by the
improvements authorized and ordered by a local improvement district. (1974 Code
§ 10-309)
6-6-6: DEAD OR DISEASED TREES:
   A.   Definition: The term "diseased tree" means any tree which has become
blighted, deformed, or has acquired a disease not capable of cure through
treatment or the use of any known or recognized form of spray material.
   B.   Declared Nuisance: Every dead, deformed, broken, dangerous or diseased
tree within any street, or upon private property adjacent to a street or other
public grounds, which has or may become a traffic hazard and is so determined
by the forester, is hereby declared to be and to constitute a nuisance, and the
forester is authorized to remove such nuisance in the manner provided by this
section.
   C.   Removal: Whenever, in the opinion of the forester, any such trees
within a street or upon a parkway or other public property should be removed,
the forester shall cause the same to be removed at city expense.
   D.   Private Property Adjacent To Street Or Public Ground: Whenever any such
trees, or such trees declared to be a public nuisance as provided by section
6-6-9 of this chapter, are situated upon private property adjacent to a street
or other public ground, interfere with pedestrian or public travel or otherwise
constitute a safety hazard, the forester shall cause the pruning, removal or
extermination thereof. The cost of such pruning, removal or extermination shall
be assessed against the said property in the manner provided by section
6-6-10 of this chapter. (1974 Code § 10-310)
6-6-7: SHADE TREES; DAMAGING, DESTROYING:
It shall be unlawful for any person, including the owner, lessee or occupant of
any lot or premises, to wilfully cut, injure, disfigure or destroy, or in any
way damage or mutilate any shade tree, or part thereof, or ornamental plant
growing within any street, public park or public grounds in Buhl; except that
the forester may, upon determination that any tree or part thereof within any
public right of way is subject to condemnation as provided herein, remove such
tree or part thereof. (1974 Code § 10-311)
6-6-8: PRUNING:
   A.   Required: Every owner, agent, tenant or occupant of any property shall
prune all shade trees, and shall prune and remove all parts of dead or diseased
limbs of trees, in front of the property owned or occupied by him, overhanging
the sidewalks, street or alley so that the branches thereof will not interfere
with pedestrians or public travel, or constitute a hazard.
   B.   Options: In the case of trees on the public right of way, the owner,
agent, tenant or occupant has the option of:
      1.   Doing the work himself, subject to permit and supervision by the
forester; or
      2.   Hiring a tree firm licensed by the city to do the work. (1974 Code §
10-312)
6-6-9: INJURIOUS PESTS; FAILURE TO PRUNE:
It is hereby declared to be a public nuisance:
   A.   Permit Or Cause Infestation, Spread, Or Continued Existence: To permit,
or cause to be permitted, the infestation, spread or continued existence of
injurious pests, or insects, or their eggs or larvae, upon any tree or
shrubbery upon private property or upon property in the care, custody and
control of any person or upon a parkway; and
   B.   Permit Or Cause To Remain Unpruned: For any person to permit or cause
to be permitted, any tree to remain unpruned on a parkway when such tree or the
parts or branches thereof interfere with pedestrian or public travel or
otherwise constitute a safety hazard. (1974 Code § 10-313)
6-6-10: DUTIES OF OWNERS:
   A.   Duty To Eradicate Pests And Insects And Prune: It is hereby made the
duty of every owner of any real property in the city to eradicate any and all
injurious pests or insects, or their eggs or larvae from any and all trees or
shrubbery and to cause all trees growing upon the parkway to be pruned under
the supervision of the forester. (1974 Code § 10-314)
   B.   City May Do Work; Lien: In the event any owner of property fails to
have trees or shrubbery on the parkway pruned under the supervision of the
forester, or fails to exterminate such injurious pests or insects, or their
eggs or larvae, the same shall be done by the city under the supervision of the
forester and the costs and charges incurred are hereby declared to be a lien
upon the real property owned by such person. (1974 Code § 10-315)
   C.   Record Of Assessments: After the extermination of such injurious pests
or insects or their eggs or larvae or the pruning of trees and shrubbery,
herein declared to be a nuisance, the total amount of all expenses incurred and
incidental thereto shall be certified by the forester to the council and if
found to be correct, the council shall order the same entered in a docket or
book for the collection of special assessments by the city, which book or
docket shall contain the names of the property owners, description of the
property and the amount assessed against each lot, piece or parcel thereof, and
all amounts so entered shall be declared to be a lien upon the property so
benefited. (1974 Code § 10-316)
   D.   Delinquent Assessments: The city clerk-treasurer shall give public
notice in at least three (3) consecutive issues of the official newspaper,
specifying the time in which payment of such assessment may be made and that a
penalty of seven percent (7%) will be added after delinquency, and shall also
mail a postal card to each property owner, containing the substance of said
notice, and any person may redeem his property from said assessment by paying
the principal thereof within the time specified, and in default of such
payment, the same shall become delinquent assessments, which together with the
penalty shall be certified to the county tax collector by the city clerk-
treasurer and placed upon the tax roll and collected in the same manner and
subject to the same penalty as other city taxes. (1974 Code § 10-317)
6-6-11: WORK DONE BY CITY; DISCRETION OF CITY PARKS AND TREE COMMITTEE:
Whenever the city parks and tree committee shall determine that it is to the
best interest of the city to undertake the eradication of injurious pests and
insects, or to prune trees within the city streets, the same may be done by the
department of parks, to the extent of monies available therefor, without charge
to the owners of property adjoining such streets upon which such work is done.
(1974 Code § 10-318)
6-6-12: TREES GROWN IN CONTAINERS ON STREETS:
Trees may be planted, grown, established and maintained in containers placed,
installed, erected and maintained upon public property or right of way, subject
to all provisions of this chapter, except where in conflict with this section,
and subject to the following additional conditions and regulations: (1974 Code
§ 10-319)
   A.   Compliance With Map Or Plat: It shall be unlawful for any person to
plant, grow, establish and maintain trees in containers placed, installed,
erected or maintained upon public property or right of way in and at any
location until a zoning map, as provided by subsection
6-6-2D of this chapter, is on file showing the districts or areas within which
such containers may be placed, installed, erected or maintained and showing the
type, kind, sizes and spacing of the trees and containers within such districts
or areas, or at any place or places which the forester may from time to time
specify. The forester shall designate locations where such containers shall be
placed, installed, erected or maintained and reserve the right to change, alter
or amend designation of said location or locations as public convenience and
necessity may from time to time require. (1974 Code § 10-319; amd. 2010 Code)
   B.   Permit Required: It shall be unlawful or any person to place, install,
erect or maintain any such container in the city without first securing a
permit therefor.
      1.   Written Application: No such permit shall be issued except upon
written application showing proposed location of each container and such other
information as the forester shall require.
      2.   Damage To City Property: No installation will be permitted which
will cause damage to the property of the city.
      3.   Obstruction Or Hazard: No permits shall be issued if the
installation, erection or maintenance of any such container should tend to
obstruct the passage along any public way or create a hazard or would otherwise
be detrimental to the public safety, welfare or convenience.
   C.   Container, Tree, Spacing, And Location: The forester, with the approval
of the city parks and tree committee, shall prescribe the type and kind of
container, types and kinds of trees, and the spacing and location of the
container or containers which shall be shown on the zoning map referred to in
subsection A of this section and in subsection
6-6-2D of this chapter, which types, kinds, spacing and locations may be in
addition to the conditions and regulations provided by subsections
6-6-2B, C, and D of this chapter. No permittee shall locate or maintain any
container or containers except in conformity with the provisions of this
section.
   D.   Supervision: The forester shall supervise the installation, erection,
maintenance or removal of all containers licensed hereunder, and said forester
shall have charge of, prescribe and regulate, subject to the provisions of this
chapter, the replacement or removal of trees planted, grown, established and
maintained in such containers.
   E.   Maintenance: It shall be the duty of the permittee, his, their or its
successors, assigns, transferees or agents, to maintain each container at all
times in a safe condition and in its proper, lawful location and to maintain
the trees therein.
   F.   Assignment Or Transfer: Each permit may be assigned and transferred,
but notice of such assignment or transfer must be given to the forester.
   G.   Revocation: Any permit may be revoked for any violation of any of the
provisions of this section and chapter. If any permit is revoked in accordance
with the provisions of this section, the permittee, his, their or its
successors, assigns, transferees or agents, shall remove the container or
containers from public property within ten (10) days from the date he, they or
it are so ordered, or the city shall remove and store the container or
containers at the permittee's, or his, their, or its successors', assigns',
transferees' or agents' expense. Any permit issued under this section shall be
canceled and revoked if the permittee, his, their or its successors, assigns,
transferees or agents, fails to place, install, erect or maintain such
container or containers within sixty (60) days after issuance of the permit.
(1974 Code § 10-319)
6-6-13: VIOLATION; PENALTY:
Any person violating any of the provisions of this chapter shall be deemed
guilty of an infraction. (Ord. 991, 10-11-2018)
CHAPTER 7
FRANCHISES

6-7-2: Nonexclusive Franchises
6-7-1: GAS AND ELECTRICITY FRANCHISES 1 :
The providing of gas and electricity to the city must be franchised in the city
under agreements between the franchisee and the city. (2010 Code)
 
Notes

6-7-2: NONEXCLUSIVE FRANCHISES:
The city council shall have the power to issue nonexclusive franchises. (2010
Code)
CHAPTER 8
WORK IN PUBLIC STREETS AND RIGHTS-OF-WAY
SECTION:
6-8-1: Permit Required
6-8-2: Application And Permits
6-8-3:Denial Of Application
6-8-4: Approval Of Permits
6-8-5: Progress Of Work
6-8-6: Safety, Warning Signs, And Barricades
6-8-7: Ditching Across Public Right Of Way
6-8-8: Awnings
6-8-9: Use Restrictions
6-8-10: Weight Restrictions
6-8-11: Council May Order Construction
6-8-12: Sidewalks, Curbs, And Driveway Approaches
6-8-13: Liability For Damages Or Injuries Occurring On Sidewalks, Curbs And
Driveway Approaches
6-8-14: Inspections, Street Restoration, And Bond Requirements
6-8-15: Permit Fees
6-8-16: Suspension, Revocation, Or Modification Of Permit
6-8-17: Cuts On New Pavement Prohibited
6-8-1: PERMIT REQUIRED:
It is unlawful for any person, firm, or corporation, other that authorized City
employees, to commence to repair, improve, alter, or otherwise perform any
street maintenance or work upon the public streets or Rights-of-Way within the
City without first having obtained a permit from the Public Works Director. In
granting a permit under this Chapter, the Director shall have the authority to
impose any conditions necessary to safeguard the public interest, including,
but not limited to, conditions on use, construction, indemnity, insurance, and
compensation to the City for degradation of the useful life of streets and the
Rights-of-Way. (Ord. 2024-05, 5-13-2024)
6-8-2: APPLICATION AND PERMITS:
Any person, firm or corporation required to obtain a permit for work in, or
business use of, a public street or Rights-of-Way shall file an application
therefor with the Director of the Department of Public Works. The application
shall be in writing, shall conform to the City Specifications and Standard
Drawings and any amendments thereto, and shall be upon forms provided by the
City. It shall contain information showing the type of construction, the
length, the exact location, the purposes, and other information which may be
required by the Public Works Director. The provisions of this section shall
apply to any person, firm or corporation qualified for and seeking permits for
street openings or work in the public streets and Rights-of-Way of the City.
(Ord. 2024-05, 5-13-2024)
6-8-3: DENIAL OF APPLICATION:
Wherever work in the public streets of Rights-of-Way within the City will
create an exceptional traffic hazard or will unreasonably restrict the use of
City streets, will create and impediment to the free movement of vehicles upon
the aforementioned streets, or a hazard to the travel or safety of pedestrians
thereon, the Public Works Director, at his/her discretion, may deny any
application, or part thereof, made under the terms of this Chapter. (Ord. 2024-
05, 5-13-2024)
6-8-4: APPROVAL OF PERMITS:
Permits for any work involving the removal or destruction of any street
surfacing, curb, curb and gutter, sidewalks, signs or other structure with
public right-of-way shall be approved by the City Engineer.
A permit for performing work in or upon any public right-of-way shall not
relieve the permittee of responsibility for the safety of water lines, sewer
lines, electrical cables, conduit or any other structures, material or
equipment which may be either above or below the ground, nor shall any such
permit allow the permittee to enter upon private property.
Permits shall not be granted for any improvement, excavation, fill,
construction, repairs or any other work within the public right-of-way unless
the contemplated work includes the construction of curb on all streets
adjoining the property where adequate curbing does not exist at the time of
application nor shall any permit be granted for any work within the streets
adjoining any business property unless the contemplated work includes the
construction of curb and sidewalk on all streets adjoining the property where
adequate curing and sidewalks do not exist at the time of application, except
that in the Manufacturing Zones, as defined in this Code, this requirement may
be waived on approval of the City Council.
Permits shall not be granted for any work within or upon any public right-of-
way bordering on any property having motor vehicle fuel pumps, driveway
approaches, signs, sidewalks, curbs or other structures which do not conform to
the existing requirements unless such times are to be reconstructed, removed or
altered to conform to the existing requirements and regulations.
Permits shall not be granted for the use of any material other than Portland
cement concrete for any new construction bordering on any business property
within the space between the property line and the curb line of any street.
(Ord. 2024-05, 5-13-2024)
6-8-5: PROGRESS OF WORK:
Whenever any work is done in or upon any public right-of-way, such work shall,
when once commenced, be continued to completion without unnecessary delay. If,
at any time during the progress of the work, the work is left unattended for a
period of more than twenty-four (24) hours, the superintendent of streets may
restore the site to its original condition and the person responsible for the
work shall be billed for the expense of such restoration. (Ord. 2024-05, 5-13-
2024)
6-8-6: SAFETY, WARNING SIGNS, AND BARRICADES:
The safety requirements of the City and of the state of Idaho, as applicable to
any work for which a permit is required hereunder, shall be observed.
Anyone doing any work in or upon any public right-of-way, whether by permit or
otherwise, shall if such work is not completed before sunset, provide a minimum
of four 4. flares or lights and keep them burning throughout the hours from
sunset to sunrise. (Ord. 2024-05, 5-13-2024)
6-8-7: DITCHING ACROSS PUBLIC RIGHT OF WAY:
When, for any reason, it is necessary to run a ditch of any depth across more
than one-half (1/2) the width of any street, excavation and backfilling shall
be completed on one-half (1/2) of the street before any excavation is started
on the other half. Whenever such ditching is to be done, the person responsible
for the work shall inform the police and fire departments not less than two 2.
hours before the work is scheduled to start and shall notify the police and
fire departments as soon as the work is completed. Backfilling shall be done in
accordance with city specifications for sewer construction. (Ord. 2024-05, 5-
13-2024)
6-8-8: AWNINGS:
It shall be unlawful for any person to place, erect, construct or maintain any
awning, shade or other structure of any kind or for any purpose over or above
the sidewalk space of any street or avenue within the city, unless each and
every part thereof other than the cloth or fabric covering shall be at least
seven feet (7') above the surface of the sidewalk, and unless each and every
part of the cloth or other fabric covering and fringe be at least six and one-
half feet (6 ½’) above the sidewalk. Provided, that this section does not, and
shall not, be deemed to affect or change in any way the provisions for height
or electric or other signs. (Ord. 2024-05, 5-13-2024)
6-8-9: USE RESTRICTIONS:
   A.   Fires: It shall be unlawful for any person to set or maintain a fire on
any public right-of-way.
   B.   Rubbish And Waste: It shall be unlawful for any person to sweep, throw,
drop, leave or otherwise place any paper, rubbish, dirt, ashes, waste, trash,
weeds, grass, or other like substances on any public right-of-way.
   C.   Obstruction of Streets: It shall be unlawful for any person to obstruct
in any way any public right-of-way except by permit issued under this code.
   D.   Horses And Animals: It shall be unlawful for any person to leave any
horse, mule or team standing in any street or public place or an enclosure
without a rider or driver, unless such horse, mule or team is securely
fastened.
   E.   Driving Over Curb: It shall be unlawful for any person to drive or
cause to be driven any vehicle, team, or wagon over or upon any curbing or
sidewalk, except at locations where an approved crossing has been provided.
(Ord. 2024-05, 5-13-2024)
6-8-10: WEIGHT RESTRICTIONS:
It shall be unlawful to drive or haul or cause to be driven or hauled any
vehicle of which the weight, or distribution of the weight or the length of a
single vehicle, or the combined length of joined vehicles or the width shall
exceed in any respect that or those allowed by any statue of the state now or
hereafter in effect, or any regulation of the state highway department now or
hereafter in effect, or any regulation of any highway district in the city
which now is or hereafter may be in effect; or to drive or haul, or cause to be
driven or hauled, any vehicle having projecting hard knobs or parts upon any of
its wheels, except upon permission of the city engineer, which permit shall
designate the street or streets to be traveled; or to move any weight or
article upon or over any street or streets to be traveled; or to move any
weight or article upon or over any street unless the same be mounted upon, and
the weight thereof borne by wheels. Provided, however, that this section shall
not apply to the moving of buildings under special permit by the city council
or to the operation of any vehicles or equipment by the City in the care of or
work upon its streets and alleys. (Ord. 2024-05, 5-13-2024)
6-8-11: COUNCIL MAY ORDER CONSTRUCTION:
The City Council may from time to time by order or resolution entered upon its
minutes, order and direct the construction or repair of any sidewalk in the
manner designated in the order and when any sidewalk shall be ordered built,
rebuilt or repaired, and the owner shall fail or neglect to build, rebuild or
repair the same, the same may be done by the Superintendent of Streets or by
the contractors who may agree to do the same, and such contract shall be
awarded to the lowest responsible bidder therefor. The City Clerk shall, as the
City Council may direct, advertise for bids the construction of sidewalks in a
newspaper published in the City.
The Clerk shall, upon the passage of any order or resolution of the Council
directing the building or repair of any sidewalk, cause a written notice to be
served on the owner or owners of the property abutting, fronting on or adjacent
to the sidewalks to be constructed, notifying them to construct the same in
accordance with the provisions of this Chapter and the order or resolution
directing the construction of the same, within fifteen (15) days from the date
of the service of said notice, which notice may be served by delivering a copy
thereof to the owner or owners, his or their agent, or by leaving a copy
thereof at the usual place of abode or the owner with any member of the owner’s
family over the age of fifteen (15) years. In case any owner is a nonresident,
or his place of abode cannot be found, then the Clerk shall cause said notice
to be published for four 4. weeks in a newspaper published in the City.
If, at the expiration of the time for which said notice is given, the said
sidewalk shall not be built by the owner of the property abutting, fronting on
or adjacent to the same, then the Superintendent of Streets or contractor shall
proceed as soon as practicable to construct the proper sidewalk as provided by
this Code, and in accordance with the order or resolution directing the
construction of the same.
When any sidewalk shall need repairing or rebuilding to conform to the
requirements of this Code, the Superintendent of Streets may cause notice
signed by the City Clerk to be given to the owner of the property fronting on
or abutting on or adjacent to such walk requiring the repair to be made within
fifteen (15) days, or the rebuilding to be done in fifteen (15) days, or
demonstrate within fifteen (15) days that they are attempting to start
construction. The serving of notice shall be made in the same manner as
provided above and if the same is not repaired or rebuilt within the time above
specified, it may be repaired or rebuilt by the Superintendent of Streets or
contractor in the same manner and upon the same terms as provided for first
construction.
As soon as the building, rebuilding or repairing of any sidewalk shall be
completed, the sidewalk shall be inspected by the City Engineer, and if it be
constructed or repaired in conformity with this Code and the order or
resolution ordering the same and the contract, if one is made, a certificate
shall be issued to the Superintendent of Streets or contractor as the case may
be, which shall state the amount of sidewalk constructed by the Superintendent
of Streets or contractor, the street or avenue, where constructed and the
description of the lots and blocks in front of, abutting on or adjacent to
which such sidewalk is built and the amount due for that fronting on, abutting
or adjacent to each lot.
Upon the presentation of one or more such certificates to the City Clerk, he
shall assess the amount of such certificates separately upon the lost fronting,
abutting on or adjacent to the sidewalks built or repaired, and record and file
the assessment roll in his office. At the next regular meeting of the City
Council the Clerk shall notify said Council of the fact that he has made such
assessment.
The City Clerk shall immediately thereafter give the lot owner notice of such
assessment by publication for a period of three 3. days in a newspaper
published in the City, notifying such owner to appear before the Council at its
next regular meeting, giving time and place of such meeting, that such property
owner may be heard before the Council as to the justness and correctness of the
amount so assessed.
In case the owner shall fail to pay such assessment of fail to appear and make
objections or shall fail to have his objections sustained by the Council, then
the assessment, unless the same be paid within ten (10) days after such
hearing, shall be certified by the City Clerk to the proper County officer
having custody of the tax list of Twin Falls County, at the time the said
certificate is made, in the same manner as other City taxes are certified to
said officer.
All such assessments shall be known as special assessments for sidewalk and
shall be levied and collected as a separate tax in addition to the taxes for
general revenue purposes to be placed on the tax roll for collection, subject
to the same penalties and collected in the same manner as other City taxes.
As soon as the City Clerk has so certified such assessment he shall draw and
issue a warrant to the contractor or Superintendent of Streets for the amount
called for in the certificate by the City Engineer upon the sidewalk fund which
shall be signed by the proper officers of the City and registered in the office
of the City Treasurer.
All warrants so issued shall be payable out of the moneys collected by the
County Collector from said sidewalk assessment and the City shall in no event
be liable on such warrants except to the amount collected from said assessment.
When any warrant drawn on the sidewalk fund is presented to the City Treasurer
for payment and there are no funds in the Treasury for the payment of the same,
the Treasurer shall endorse upon the bank of said warrant the date of
presentation for payment with words “No Funds” and any and all warrants to
endorsed shall bear interest from the date of presentation and endorsement by
the Treasurer at the rate of seven percent (7%) per annum. (Ord. 2024-05, 5-13-
2024)
6-8-12: SIDEWALKS, CURBS, AND DRIVEWAY APPROACHES:
   A.   Property Owner Responsibility: Sidewalks, curbs and driveway approaches
shall be constructed and repaired by the owners of the property adjoining the
location of the work at their expense, at such times and in such places and
manner as herein provided. The City Engineer is hereby authorized and directed
to inspect all such work and to obtain compliance with this Code and the
specifications and drawings herein referred to.
   B.   Regulations: It shall be unlawful for any person to lay, place or
construct any crossing over curbing in the City by means of cutting or removing
such curb, or otherwise, without first obtaining a permit from the City
Engineer to be issued according to the regulations contained herein.
      Any property owner desiring to obtain a permit for a service driveway or
driveways to serve his property, shall file application therefor with the City
Engineer. Said application shall be in writing and upon a form provided by the
City and shall contain information showing the type of construction, the length
of driveway desired, location of driveway and any other information which may
be required by the City Engineer.
      The permit fee for cutting a curb shall be established in the official
fee schedule of the city.
      If the proposed alteration as set forth in said application conforms with
the regulations herein contained and amendments thereof, the City Engineer
shall issue a permit therefor.
      The city council reserves the right to review any decision of the city
engineer upon any application and to permit curb cuts for a distance more that
thirty-five feet (35') in a commercial or manufacturing district where it
appears that it is necessary to accommodate large trucks and trailers. The
public welfare, safety and convenience shall be considered in granting any such
application.
   C.   Line And Grades: All lines and grades for all construction within the
public right-of-way shall be established by the city engineer. If sidewalks,
curbing, driveway approaches or other construction in the public right-of-way
is not set to the lines and grades as established by the city engineer, the
city council may direct removal and reconstruction to the proper grades. (Ord.
2024-05, 5-13-2024)
6-8-13: LIABILITY FOR DAMAGES OR INJURIES OCCURRING ON SIDEWALKS, CURBS AND
DRIVEWAY APPROACHES:
Since the owners of property adjoining right-of-way are responsible for the
construction and repair of sidewalks, curbs and driveway approaches, the city,
its officers and employees shall not be liable for injuries or damages
resulting from a failure to construct, rebuild or repair sidewalks, curbs and
driveway approaches. (Ord. 2024-05, 5-13-2024)
6-8-14: INSPECTIONS, STREET RESTORATION, AND BOND REQUIREMENTS:
   A.   Inspections: The Department of Public Works, or qualified designee,
shall inspect Rights-of-Way occupancy permit locations/sites to evaluate the
condition of public infrastructure (including but not limited to; curb/gutter,
sidewalk, roadway/street and alley paving, grading, drainage structures,
bridges [vehicular and pedestrian], railings, retaining walls, boulevard or
median improvements, driveway approaches, alley approaches, curb and pavement
markings, traffic management structures, public utility connections and other
related appurtenances to determine if any harm, damage, degradation, or other
adverse condition to the public infrastructure has occurred. Any/all resultant
harm, damage, degradation, or other adverse condition to the public
infrastructure shall be fully restored to prior condition or better, as
determined feasible and/or appropriate by the Public Works Department. The
permittee accepts full responsibility, including any/all resultant costs, for
restoration of the public infrastructure. Failure to comply with restoration
requirements may result in the City completing the restoration work and;
      1.   Assessing the person, firm, or corporation; and
      2.   Drawing against the bonds posted by one or more licensed
contractors; and
      3.   Refusing future ROW permits for nonperformance until performance
issues are resolved.
   B.   Street Restoration:
      1.   The permittee, or its agent or contractor, shall restore, repair,
and replace any portion of the improvements or infrastructure located within
Rights-of-Way that is damaged or disturbed by the permittee’s work in or
adjacent to the Rights-of-Way.
      2.   If the permittee fails to timely restore, repair, or replace the
Rights-of-Way as required in this subsection, the City or its contractor may do
so and the permittee shall pay the City’s reasonable costs and expenses in
completing the restoration, repair or replacement including reasonable
attorney’s fees and expenses.
   C.   Video Inspections: All projects utilizing directional drilling
techniques with public right-of-way shall provide to the City a post-
construction video inspection of sewer mains and laterals within the
construction area documenting that the sewer system was not damaged by
construction activities.
   D.   Bond Requirements: The Public Works Director is authorized to require a
bond, or deposit, from any permittee under this Chapter, to guarantee the
restoration of the street and Rights-of-Way or use thereof to its original
condition and to compensate the City for the degradation of the street and
Rights-of-Way.
      Bond amounts shall be at the discretion of the Public Works Director,
utilizing commonly used estimation formulas for Public Works Construction.
(Ord. 2024-05, 5-13-2024)
6-8-15: PERMIT FEES:
   A.   Permits required under this Chapter specifying the authorized work
shall be issued by the Public Works Director, or their designee, upon proper
application therefore and upon payment of the fees required as follows;
      1.   A basic fee in the amount established by the City; and
      2.   The estimated cost of administration and inspection as determined by
the Public Works Director, including the City’s labor, overhead and all other
costs for street work, said amount shall not exceed 20% percent of the
estimated cost of construction.
      3.   In the event that reinspection or other actions are necessary, an
additional fee shall be charged in an amount determined by the Public Works
Director to equal the City’s costs of performing the reinspection or other
actions, including all labor, overhead and other costs.
      4.   A payment of all related street degradation costs.
      5.   Any permit for temporary use or occupation of the public Rights-of-
Way, where there is no construction involved, shall not require payment of a
degradation cost as part of the permit fee.
      6.   Before a permit is issued pursuant to this article, the applicant
shall pay to the City a permit application fee, which shall be determined in
accordance with a fee schedule adopted by the City from time to time.
   B.   Fees will be reasonably related to the costs inherent in managing the
public Rights-of-Way. As used in this Chapter, these costs include, but are not
necessarily limited to:
      1.   The costs of permitting Rights-of-Way occupant(s),
      2.   Verifying Rights-of-Way occupation(s),
      3.   Mapping Rights-of-Way occupation(s),
      4.   Inspecting job site(s) and Rights-of-Way restoration(s),
      5.   Administering this Chapter,
      6.   Costs relating to the degradation of the Rights-of-Way (i.e., the
cost to achieve a level of restoration as determined by the City at the time
the permit is issued); and
      7.   Disruption costs resulting from traffic disruption and delay.
   C.   The portion of the permit fee relating to degradation costs shall be
reduced by the City in cases where the applicant demonstrates to the
satisfaction of the Public Works Director that the excavation proposed will be
used by two 2. or more entities, legally and financially unrelated, for the
installation, maintenance, or repair of facilities.
   D.   The degradation cost portion of the permit fee shall be further reduced
in cases where the applicant demonstrates to the satisfaction of the Public
Works Director that the excavation to be made will be commenced and completed
during the twelve-month period immediately prior to the scheduled repaving or
resurfacing of a street, as indicated in the most recent edition of the City’s
repaving plan. (Ord. 2024-05, 5-13-2024)
6-8-16: SUSPENSION, REVOCATION, OR MODIFICATION OF PERMIT:
   A.   The Public Works Director may suspend, revoke, or modify any permit
issued under this section when such permit holder, or any party to the permit:
      1.   Violates any of the terms and requirements outlined in the approved
permit;
      2.   Exceeds the scope of the use of work outlined in the permit
application;
      3.   Has obtained a permit by fraud, misrepresentation, concealment, or
through inadvertence or mistake; or
      4.   Makes a misrepresentation or fails to disclose a material fact to
the City related to any of the obligations set forth in this Chapter. (Ord.
2024-05, 5-13-2024)
6-8-17: CUTS IN NEW PAVEMENT PROHIBITED:
   A.   For the purposes of this section, “new pavement” includes any paving or
surface treatment that has been in place less that five 5. years; nominal
surface treatments such as chip, slurry, or fog seals are excluded from this
definition.
   B.   A permit to cut new pavement shall not be granted. Permittees shall
determine alternate methods to avoid cutting new pavement.
   C.   Exceptions:
      1.   Emergency which endangers life or property;
      2.   Interruption of essential utility service;
      3.   Work that is mandated by City or by state, or federal legislation;
      4.   Service for buildings or customers where no other feasible means of
providing service exists; and
      5.   Cuts smaller that two 2. square feet, only permitted outside of a
wheel path as determined by Public Works Director.
   D.   Permits issued under C.1. to C.4. above require mill and inlays of all
lanes affected. Unless otherwise specified by the Public Works Director or
their designee, mill and inlays shall extend at least one hundred (100) feet on
arterials, or at least fifty (50) feet on collectors.
   E.   Permits issued under C.5. above shall be in accordance with the City
Specifications and Standard Drawings. (Ord. 2024-05, 5-13-2024)
TITLE 7
PUBLIC UTILITIES
CHAPTER 1
WATER SYSTEM REGULATIONS AND PROTECTION
SECTION:
7-1-1: Definitions
7-1-2: Request For Hookup; Fees

7-1-1: DEFINITIONS:
Unless the context specifically indicates otherwise, the meaning of terms used
in this chapter shall be as follows:
CHARGES AGAINST THE PREMISES: Charges made under this chapter, the payment of
which is secured by ownership of the premises and not by a security deposit.
CHARGES AGAINST THE SECURITY DEPOSIT: Charges made under this chapter, the
payment of which is secured by a security deposit and not by ownership of the
premises.
DIRECTOR: Director of public works who shall be responsible for the operation
of the city water system.
INDIVIDUAL USER: A user whose primary use of water is for domestic and
irrigation use.
MONTH: A month as used herein shall mean the period between scheduled water
meter readings. The city will, as nearly as possible, schedule the water meter
readings thirty (30) days apart.
OWNER: Refers to the property owner, or his duly authorized representative such
as tenant, developer, lease holder, etc., that is served by the water system.
PERSON: Any individual, firm, company, association, society, corporation, or
group.
SERVICE LINES: Service lines include all water lines or pipes used to deliver
city water from the water meter to the place of use.
UNIT: A term sometimes used to define a separate water user where two (2) or
more water users are served through one water meter.
USER: Any person or owner who receives a separate billing from the city for
services rendered by the water system.
VARIABLES: Used in computing water use rates:
   A.   C = Total water use charge.
   B.   CU = Individual unit water use charge.
   C.   G = Monthly water meter reading in gallons.
   D.   U = Number of individual units.
   E.   V = Monthly individual unit water use.
WATER SYSTEM: Includes all components and facilities of the public water system
that are owned, operated, and maintained by the city for domestic and other
uses. (1974 Code § 1-501)
7-1-2: REQUEST FOR HOOKUP; FEES:
   A.   Application: Application for the hookup of water must be made at the
office of the city clerk-treasurer on such forms as may be required by the
city. Service will not be provided until all forms have been properly completed
and signed and all costs required have been paid to the city, in advance. All
services shall be governed by this title and such rules and regulations as may
be prescribed by the city council. (1974 Code § 1-502)
   B.   Fees:
      1.   Paid In Advance: Before water meters can be installed and connected
to the city water mains or laterals, the installation and hookup fee set by
resolution of the city council and approved by the mayor must be paid in full
to the city clerk-treasurer.
      2.   Users Outside City Limits: The hookup fees to be charged to any
owners or users outside the city limits of the city shall equal one and one-
half (11/2) of the hookup fee or charge assessable to an owner or user within
the city limits and as set forth in subsection B1 of this section. (1974 Code §
1-503)
7-1-3: METERS:
   A.   Required; Location: All water will be measured by means of a meter
supplied by the city. The meter shall be placed at a point to be designated by
the director of public works between the city mains or laterals and the service
line.
   B.   Furnished By City; Installation: All meters shall be furnished by the
city. All meters shall remain the property of the city and must be installed by
the city under the direction, supervision and control of the director of public
works. All meters shall be returned to the city upon their removal from the
city water system.
   C.   Replacement:
      1.   City To Replace: The city shall replace all meters which wear out
from normal use at the city's expense, said expense having been paid by the
user as part of the water hookup fee and the water fees paid.
      2.   Owner To Replace:
         a.   Larger Or Smaller Meter Requested: The owner will be responsible
for the expense of replacing a meter with a larger or smaller meter when the
owner requests such replacement.
         b.   Damaged Or Destroyed: The owner shall be responsible to replace,
at the owner's expense, all water meters or parts thereof damaged or destroyed
by the real property owner or other persons known or unknown. (1974 Code § 1-
504)
7-1-4: SERVICE LINES:
   A.   Property Owner To Repair And Protect: It is the responsibility of the
property owner receiving water through a service line to keep the same in
repair and protected from freezing. The city will not work on service lines.
   B.   Damage Resulting From Leaks Or Breaks: The owner shall be responsible
for all damage resulting from leaks or breaks in owner's service line. The city
shall have no responsibility for the installation, maintenance or repair of
such service lines, nor shall the city have any liability for damage resulting
from the leakage or breakage of a service line. (1974 Code § 1-505)
   C.   Frozen Lines; Flat Fee: Should an owner's service line freeze and said
freezing results in the damage to the water meter and/or the city water lines
and the city is called upon to thaw the city line or water meter, there shall
be a flat fee of one hundred dollars ($100.00) plus the cost of any materials
used by the city charged to the owner of the frozen service line; such fees
shall be added to the next utility bill. (1974 Code § 1-505; amd. Ord. 965, 10-
22-2012)
7-1-5: ACCESS FOR INSPECTION:
Officers and employees of the city shall have free access to all buildings to
which water may be delivered from the city mains and the location of all city
water meters for the purpose of inspecting conditions of the pipes, fixtures
and meters and the reading of water meters. No structures shall be constructed,
erected or maintained nor any vehicles parked so as to interfere with such
access. The owner must control all dogs or other pets so that they do not
interfere with such access. Failure to keep the meter accessible for meter
reading may result in a charge for returning to read the meter. (1974 Code § 1-
506)
7-1-6: DAMAGE IN CASE OF SHUTOFF:
The city water may be shut off from the mains at any time, without notice, for
the purpose of making repairs, extensions, or other necessary purposes. Persons
having boilers supplied by direct pressure from the mains are cautioned against
danger of explosion or collapse. The city shall not be responsible for the
safety of boilers on the premises of any water consumer, nor for any damage
caused a property owner as a result of a shutoff. When water is to be shut off
out of the mains of the city on a planned shutoff, the water department shall
notify the fire department and property owners prior to the time of making such
shutoff using the best method of notice available. (1974 Code § 1-507)
7-1-7: TWO HOMES OR BUILDINGS ON ONE METER:
   A.   Prohibited: No new construction or remodeling will be allowed which
will place two (2) or more houses, buildings or structures on one meter.
   B.   Existing Conditions; Billing Procedures: Under existing conditions
where two (2) or more parties receive water through one water meter, one water
statement for the meter will be issued and the following billing procedures
will be followed:
      1.   Minimum Billing: The minimum billing will equal the minimum fees for
city services times the number of units receiving services through the one
meter or the actual use, whichever is greater.
      2.   One Statement: One statement for the meter will be sent to the owner
of the property served, said owner shall be responsible for paying said
statement. Default in payment will result in a shutoff order being issued for
the meter.
      3.   Repeated Shutoff Orders: In the event repeated shutoff orders are
issued for a water meter statement, the city may require that each user have a
separate water meter, the cost of which shall be paid by the property owner.
(1974 Code § 1-508)
7-1-8: POWER TO WITHHOLD WATER:
   A.   Violation; Failure To Pay: The city may withhold water for any
violation of this chapter, for public health or safety reasons, for failure to
have backflow prevention devices (article A of this chapter), or for failure to
pay debts due the city.
   B.   Multiple Units Or Premises; Failure Of Either To Comply: Where two (2)
or more units or premises are supplied from the same service line, failure on
the part of either of such units to comply with this chapter shall warrant the
director of public works in withholding the supply of water through such
service line, until a separate service line, with a separate meter for each
user, is installed for each user at said user's expense.
   C.   Unauthorized Hose Or Pipe: No aboveground or buried water hose or other
unauthorized pipe may be used to supply water from one user to a second user.
(1974 Code § 1-509)
7-1-9: REQUEST FOR SERVICE AND SHUTOFFS:
Should a person, corporation or legal entity desire to obtain city water
service or to discontinue the use of city water, a request for such must be
given to the city clerk-treasurer at city hall on such forms as the city shall
provide. All required deposits and outstanding bills with the city shall be due
and payable. (1974 Code § 1-510)
7-1-10: WATER RATES:
   A.   Basis For Water User Charges: There is hereby established a system of
periodic service charges and fees for the use of, and for services rendered by,
the city water system, which charges and fees shall be as near as possible
proportional to the services rendered by said water system. The rates, charges
and fees shall be sufficient to produce the revenue required to maintain,
repair, operate, administer and improve the system and pay all loans, bonds, or
other debts incurred to do so. The rates, charges and fees provided by this
chapter are hereby levied and assessed against the user having any water
service connection with the city water system. It is specifically enacted that
