all property in the city to which the water system is available, but is not
used by the owner or occupier of said parcel of land, is still subject to user
charges under the provisions of this chapter as recompense for availability of
service and other benefits. (1974 Code § 1-511)
   B.   Rate Committee:
      1.   Created; Membership; Confirmation: There is hereby created a Rate
Committee consisting of seven (7) members, who are as follows: a) the City
Clerk, b) the Director of Public Works, c) the City Treasurer, d) the City
Engineer and e) three (3) citizens of Buhl appointed by the Mayor; one will
represent commercial users, one will represent industrial users and one will
represent residential users; all must be approved by the City Council. The City
Water Department Manager and the City Waste Water Department Manager shall be
adjunct members of the Rate Committee. The Rate Committee shall be confirmed by
the City Council and all decisions made by the Rate Committee shall be subject
to approval of the City Council.
      2.   Chairperson: The City Engineer shall be the Chairperson of the Rate
Committee.
      3.   Meetings: The Rate Committee shall meet at least one time a year and
at such additional times as called by the Chairperson or three (3) members.
      4.   Duties: At least once annually the Rate Committee shall evaluate the
monthly service charges for the City water, sewer and sanitation system and
recommend changes to the City Council in administration, water use, and other
rates as required to operate, maintain, administer and/or improve the City
water, sewer and sanitation system.
      5.   Individual Unit User Appraisal:
         a.   Appraisal; Assessment: Each type of individual water user and
parcel being subject to a water user charge as provided in this section shall
be appraised and assessed by the Rate Committee for the purpose of establishing
the individual unit user rating and the monthly service charge or fee for
individual unit water use service, to be charged or assessed to and against
such property. In making such appraisal, the Rate Committee shall utilize the
unit rating adopted by resolution of the City Council. The unit rating shall be
sum of all units served by a single water meter.
         b.   Example Computation For Multiple Users Through Single Meter: An
example computation for a planned unit development user obtaining all of his
water through a single water meter and consisting of ten (10) single-family
residences, a mobile home court with twenty (20) spaces, five (5) duplexes, and
a motel with twelve (12) units, is as follows:
 
Single-family residences 10 units
Mobile home court        20 units
Duplexes                 10 units
Motel:    First unit  1 unit
    Next 10 units     5 units
    Next 1 unit       1/4 unit
Total:                   461/4 units
 
The total unit rating for this user would be forty seven (47) units. All
fractions of units obtained after summation shall be rounded up to the next
largest whole unit. (Ord. 986, 8-14-2017)
   C.   Water Rates Within City Limits: All owners within the City limits who
derived benefit from the City water system shall, in return for said benefit,
pay monthly user charges established by resolution of the City Council. The
total monthly user charge shall be the sum of separate monthly charges for
administration, water usage and such other expenses deemed proper by the City
Council.
      1.   Administration rate: The monthly service charge to administer the
water system.
      2.   Water user rate: The monthly service charge to provide water for use
from the water system.
   D.   Water Rates Outside City Limits: All owners outside the City who derive
benefit from the City water and/or sewer system shall, in return for said
benefit, pay monthly user charges equal to one and one-half (11/2) times the
monthly charge otherwise chargeable to an owner within the City as computed
above, unless the City determines that, because of special circumstances, the
fee should be more or less than one and one-half (11/2) times the fee, in which
case the Rate Committee may be asked to determine the fee.
   E.   Notification To Users Of Income And Expense Of Water System: Upon any
rate change, the City shall inform users that an income and expense statement
for the water system is available at City Hall for their inspection and
copying. (1974 Code § 1-511)
   F.   Faulty Meter; Rate To Be Paid: If, for any reason, a meter is faulty or
fails to register the correct amount of water used, the rate shall be fixed at
an estimated rate of use based upon a historical review of the facts presented
by the user and the city and past consumptive records. The director of public
works, or the director's designee, shall establish a settlement rate based upon
such information. (1974 Code § 1-512)
7-1-11: DEPOSIT FOR TURN ON:
   A.   Nonproperty Owner: Every user of water, purchasing the same from the
city, who is not a real property owner in said city, shall, before being
supplied with water, deliver to the city clerk-treasurer a deposit of lawful
money of the United States Of America, as hereinafter set out, conditioned that
the said user paying to the city the rates charged for said water for such term
as it may be supplied irrespective of the place or places of delivery. The city
clerk-treasurer may return the deposit after twelve (12) billing periods have
passed if the user has not been delinquent in payment for twelve (12) or more
consecutive payments and the clerk-treasurer knows of no reason to retain the
deposit. Should the user default in payment of his or her statement, the clerk-
treasurer may demand that the deposit be once again posted with the city. (1974
Code § 1-513)
   B.   Property Owner: Every user of water, purchasing the same from the city,
who is a real property owner in the city and who does not make the deposit
provided for above, by accepting said water, consents to the city filing a lien
against the property to which the water was delivered with the Twin Falls
County recorder, Twin Falls, Idaho, for the amount of the delinquent utility
bill plus late charges, interest and the cost of filing said lien.
   C.   Statement Placed In Name Of Property Owner: Any real property owner may
have the water statement placed in his/her name and water, etc., will be
provided to the renter on the owner's account with no deposit being required.
However, the real property owner will be personally liable for said utility
bill and subsection B of this section shall apply. (1974 Code § 1-513; amd.
Ord. 965, 10-22-2012)
   D.   Amount Of Deposit: The amount of said deposit shall be the greater
amount of the following:
      1.   Two (2) times the minimum monthly charges for monthly services
charged to said meter rounded up to the nearest five dollar ($5.00) increment.
      2.   The term "monthly service charged" to said meter includes, but is
not limited to, water, sewer and sanitation fees.
      3.   The deposit for services outside the city limits shall be one and
one-half (11/2) times the fee computed under subsection D1 or D2 of this
section.
      4.   All deposits shall be held by the city to secure payment of the
party's city water statement.
      5.   When service is terminated by the user of the service or by the city
because the account is delinquent, the deposit shall be applied first to paying
the balance due the city on the account and the balance remaining, if any,
shall be returned to the party who made the deposit if such sum is claimed at
the city hall within forty five (45) days. Unclaimed balances shall be
deposited into the city water department general fund. If any balance is due
the city after applying the deposit to payment of the account, the city may
bring civil suit for the collection of the balance or refuse city services to
such party until such balance is paid in full. (1974 Code § 1-514)
   E.   Charges To Be Paid Before Turn On:
      1.   All charges against the premises that are due and payable must be
paid by the owner of the premises, or some other person on such owner's behalf,
before water will be turned on to the premises for which such service charge is
owed.
      2.   All charges against the security deposit that are due and payable,
including such that are not paid by the security deposit, must be paid by the
owner of the security deposit, or some other person on such owner's behalf,
before water will be turned on to the user who posted the original security
deposit. (1974 Code § 1-515)
7-1-12: STATEMENTS:
   A.   Meters Read Monthly: All city water meters will be read by the city on
a monthly basis.
   B.   Billing: The monthly water fee shall be part of the utility fee billed
as provided hereafter in chapter 5 of this title. (Ord. 966, 10-22-2012)
7-1-13: SPRINKLING:
   A.   Power To Regulate: The Director of Public Works, with the consent of
the City Council and Mayor, shall have the power and authority to regulate the
hours of sprinkling.
   B.   Water Shortage:
      1.   In the case of shortage of water, upon declaration or proclamation
by the Mayor, the Director of Public Works shall order the water users to
discontinue the use of sprinkler irrigation and outside use of City water from
said City water system for such time as, in the Director's opinion with the
concurrence of the Council, shall be deemed necessary.
      2.   During the period of a declaration of water shortage, no sprinkler,
open hoses, etc., shall be used for domestic irrigation, and no City water
shall be used for washing motor vehicles, driveways, patios, sidewalks or any
other outside use.
   C.   Use During Fire: All domestic irrigation shall be ceased at any time
when there is a fire burning that is being fought by the Buhl Fire Department
or any other Fire Department aiding the City. (1974 Code § 1-517)
7-1-14: TESTING:
It shall be the duty of the Director of Public Works, in accordance with State
regulations, to draw or have drawn specimens of water from at least four (4)
points in the water system, such points to be chosen by the Director of Public
Works. The water so drawn for specimens shall be submitted to a qualified
laboratory approved by the State Department of Public Health for testing as to
purity, and report on such tests shall be filed in the Office of Director of
Public Works and such other agencies as required by law. (1974 Code § 1-518)
7-1-15: CONTROL RESTS WITH MAYOR AND COUNCIL:
In all cases where this chapter places any discretion in the Director of Public
Works or the City Clerk-Treasurer, such discretion shall be subject to the
approval of the Mayor and Council. (1974 Code § 1-519)
7-1-16: TAPPING:
   A.   Done By City: All tapping of mains or laterals of the City water system
must be done by the City through the Director of Public Works and City
employees. (1974 Code § 1-520)
   B.   Done By Any Other Person: Any other person or persons doing so shall be
violating the provisions of this section. (Ord. 991, 10-11-2018)
7-1-17: TURNING ON AFTER SHUTOFF:
   A.   Prohibited: Should the owner or occupant of the premises turn on the
water, or suffer or cause it to be turned on, after it has been shut off by the
City at the water meter, the City will shut the meter off and a charge of fifty
dollars ($50.00) must be paid to the City before the same shall be turned on
again. The charge set forth herein shall be increased for repeated violations
by multiplying this charge times the repeat numbers.
   B.   Violation; Penalty: Any person turning on a City water meter after it
is shut off by the City shall be guilty of an infraction and subject to penalty
as provided in this Code, which penalty shall be in addition to any charge set
forth in subsection A of this section. (Ord. 991, 10-11-2018)
7-1-18: INHIBITING ACCESS TO METER; PENALTY:
Any person, firm or corporation who shall, in any manner, intentionally
interfere with the reading of the water meter shall be deemed guilty of an
infraction. (Ord. 991, 10-11-2018)
7-1-19: THEFT, IMPROPER USE, INTERFERENCE OR DAMAGE:
Any person, firm or corporation who shall: a) knowingly divert water service of
the City to his own benefit or the benefit of another not entitled thereto; or
b) use City water from the City water system for any purpose not stated in the
application for City water service; or c) maliciously interferes with, damages
or vandalizes any City water meter or the City water system or any part
thereof, shall be deemed guilty of an infraction and subject to penalty as
provided in this Code. (Ord. 991, 10-11-2018)
7-1-20: VIOLATION; PENALTY:
   A.   Infraction: A violation of this chapter is hereby declared to be an
infraction and the violator, upon conviction, shall be subject to penalty of
one hundred dollars ($100.00) plus court costs and fees assessed for the first
violation, two hundred dollars ($200.00) plus court costs and fees for the
second violation, and three hundred dollars ($300.00) plus court costs and fees
for the third and subsequent violations during the same calendar year;
provided, however, that in the event the damages resulting from any single
violation of this chapter exceed five hundred dollars ($500.00), such violation
is declared to be a misdemeanor. (Ord. 991, 10-11-2018)
   B.   Civil Action:
      1.   Whenever it appears to the City Council that any person has engaged
or is about to engage in any act or practice violating any provisions of this
chapter, the City Council may institute a civil action in the District Court to
enforce compliance with this chapter. Upon a showing that a person has engaged
or is about to engage in an act or practice constituting a violation of this
chapter, a permanent or temporary injunction, restraining order or other such
relief as the court deems appropriate may be granted. The City Council shall
not be required to furnish any bond in said civil processing.
      2.   The City may file a civil suit to collect any sums due the City
which were not paid when due plus attorney fees and court costs.
      3.   The City shall be entitled to costs and reasonable attorney fees on
any suits brought to enforce this chapter. (1974 Code § 1-524)
ARTICLE A. CROSS CONNECTION CONTROL
SECTION:
7-1A-1: Purpose; Scope
7-1A-2: Definitions
7-1A-3: Nuisance
7-1A-4: Connection And Discontinuance Of Service
7-1A-5: Backflow Prevention Devices
7-1A-6: Cross Connection Inspection
7-1A-7: Sprinkler Systems
7-1A-8: Enforcement
7-1A-9: Additional Remedies
7-1A-10: Civil Liability
7-1A-11: Violation; Penalty
7-1A-1: PURPOSE; SCOPE:
   A.   The purpose of this article is to protect the public health of water
consumers by the control of actual and potential cross connections. (1974 Code
§ 5-801)
   B.   Rules and regulations of the Idaho department of environmental quality
pertaining to public water supplies have specific provisions to control cross
connections in public water systems. For the purpose of protecting the health
of consumers receiving water from the city, it is considered that the
requirements established by the Idaho department of environmental quality in
Idaho rules for public drinking water systems, IDAPA 58.01.08, apply. (1974
Code § 5-801; amd. 2010 Code)
   C.   This article is adopted for the benefit of public health to water users
receiving their water supply from the city by protecting the public water
system from actual or potential contamination. (1974 Code § 5-801)
7-1A-2: DEFINITIONS:
   A.   General Definitions: The following are established as definitions for
the purpose of this article:
   BACK PRESSURE BACKFLOW: The backflow of a higher pressure nonpotable water
supply into a lower pressure potable supply.
   BACK SIPHONAGE BACKFLOW: Backflow of a nonpotable supply into a potable
water supply that is a result of negative or reduced pressure.
   BACKFLOW: The flow, other than the intended direction of flow, of any
foreign liquids, gases or substances into this city public water supply
distribution system.
   BACKFLOW PREVENTION DEVICE: A device to counteract back pressure or to
prevent back siphonage.
   CROSS CONNECTION: Any physical arrangement whereby a public water supply is
connected, directly or indirectly, with any other water supply system, sewer,
drain, conduit, pool, storage reservoir, plumbing fixture, or other device
which contains or may contain contaminated water, sewage or other waste or
liquid of unknown or unsafe quality which may be capable of contaminating the
public water supply system of this city as a result of backflow.
   B.   Additional Definitions: All definitions contained in Idaho rules for
public drinking water systems, IDAPA 58.01.08, as the same may hereafter be
revised or amended, shall be considered as definitions within the meaning of
this article. (1974 Code § 5-802)
7-1A-3: NUISANCE:
No water service connection from the city water system to any premises shall be
installed or maintained unless the city water supply is protected, as
determined to be necessary by backflow prevention devices as required by rules
and regulations of the state department of environmental quality, the Idaho
rules for public drinking water systems, and/or the AWWA PNS cross connection
and control manual and by this article. The installation or maintenance of a
cross connection which will endanger the water quality of the city water supply
system is prohibited. Any such cross connection now existing or hereafter
installed is hereby declared a nuisance and shall be abated. The control and/or
elimination of cross connection with the distribution system of the city shall
be in accordance with the rules and regulations of the state of Idaho,
department of environmental quality and the city. The city council may
establish requirements of cross connection control within this city more
stringent than state regulations. (1974 Code § 5-803)
7-1A-4: CONNECTION AND DISCONTINUANCE OF SERVICE:
Service to any property, landowner, or water user receiving its water supply
from the city water system shall be contingent upon compliance with all
requirements of the rules and regulations of the state department of
environmental quality and of this article pertaining to cross connections.
Service shall be discontinued to any premises, water user or property owner for
failure to comply with such regulations. Discontinued service will not be
reestablished until the city has approved compliance by that particular
premises, water user or landowner with such requirements of the rules and
regulations of the state department of environmental quality and of this
article pertaining to cross connections. (1974 Code § 5-804)
7-1A-5: BACKFLOW PREVENTION DEVICES:
   A.   Required: Backflow prevention devices shall be installed where, in the
judgment of the city, the nature and extent of activities or the materials
stored on the premises, would present an immediate and dangerous hazard to
health and/or be deleterious to the quality of the water should a cross
connection occur even though such cross connection does not exist at the time.
Backflow prevention devices shall be installed under circumstances including,
but not limited to, the following:
      1.   Premises having an auxiliary water supply.
      2.   Premises having internal cross connections that are not correctable,
or intricate plumbing arrangements which make it impossible to ascertain
whether or not cross connections exist.
      3.   Premises where entry is restricted or denied.
      4.   Premises having a history of cross connections being established or
reestablished.
      5.   Premises on which any substance is handled under pressure so as to
permit entry into the public water supply, or where a cross connection could
reasonably be expected to occur. This shall include the handling of process
waters and cooling waters.
      6.   Premises where materials of a toxic or hazardous nature are handled
in such a way that if back siphonage should occur, a serious health hazard
might result.
      7.   Other premises, as specified by the city, where backflow prevention
devices are required to protect the public water supply. (1974 Code § 5-805)
   B.   Type Of Protective Device: The AWWA PNWS cross connection control
manual, as it now exists or is hereafter amended, is adopted by the city by
reference and shall be followed in determining the type and installation of
cross connection control devices. A copy of the current manual being used by
the city shall be kept at the city clerk-treasurer's office at city hall. (1974
Code § 5-806)
   C.   Place Of Installation: Backflow prevention devices required by this
article shall be installed at the property line of the premises or at a
location designated by the city. The device shall be located so as to be
readily accessible for maintenance and testing, and where no part of the device
can become submerged. (1974 Code § 5-807)
   D.   Installation: Backflow prevention devices required by this article
shall be installed under the supervision of, and with the approval of, the
city. Only backflow prevention devices approved by the American Association of
Sanitary Engineers (AASE), International Association of Plumbing and Mechanical
Officials (IAPMO), and the uniform plumbing code (UPC) will be allowed. (1974
Code § 5-808)
   E.   Inspection And Testing: Backflow prevention devices installed pursuant
to this article, except atmospheric vacuum breakers, shall be inspected and
tested annually, or more often if necessary by an Idaho certified backflow
prevention device tester. Inspections, tests and maintenance shall be at the
owner's expense. Whenever the devices are found to be defective, they shall be
repaired, overhauled or replaced at the owner's expense. Annual test results
and records of supporting data, or copies thereof, must be filed with the city
department of public works. (1974 Code § 5-809)
7-1A-6: CROSS CONNECTION INSPECTION:
   A.   Required Prior To Occupancy: No water shall be delivered to any
structure hereafter built within the City or within areas served by City water
until the same has been inspected for possible cross connections and been
approved as being free of same by the Department of Public Works. The building
inspector shall not issue an occupancy permit without the Department of Public
Works inspection having been completed. Upon completion of such inspection by
the Department of Public Works, notification will be given to the building
inspector.
   B.   Periodic Inspections: Inspection shall be made periodically by the City
of all buildings, structures or improvements of any nature receiving water
through the City system for the purpose of ascertaining whether cross
connections exist. (1974 Code § 8-812)
7-1A-7: SPRINKLER SYSTEMS:
   A.   Permit Required: No underground sprinkling device will be installed
without a sprinkler installation permit issued by the City Department of Public
Works. The City Department of Public Works will have final design approval of
all new sprinkler system installations. No sprinkling system will be installed
without a sprinkler installation permit and without adequate backflow
prevention device(s) located at the point from which the water for irrigation
is taken from the public water supply. The application for a sprinkler
installation permit shall be obtained from the City Clerk-Treasurer's Office on
forms approved by the City Department of Public Works.
   B.   Inspection Of Design Plan: Upon receipt of the application, the City
Department of Public Works will inspect the design, order such changes as may
be required to comply with this article and issue a sprinkler installation
permit once the sprinkler system as built complies with this article.
   C.   Copies Of Sprinkler Installation Permit: The Department of Public Works
shall provide copies of each sprinkler installation permit to all City
departments that need a copy of such permit. (1974 Code § 5-810)
7-1A-8: ENFORCEMENT:
For the purposes of carrying out this article, the City shall be authorized to
inspect all premises receiving water service from the water supply system of
the City, as the City determines to be necessary, in order to exercise
effective cross connection control. (1974 Code § 5-811)
7-1A-9: ADDITIONAL REMEDIES:
In the event an improper cross connection is not corrected within the time
limit set by the City, or in the event the City employee authorized is refused
access to any property for the purpose of determining whether or not cross
connections exist, delivery of water to the property shall cease until the
deficiency is corrected to the satisfaction of the City. In addition, the City
may effect the necessary repairs or modifications at the property owner's
expense and refuse delivery of water to the property until the cost thereof
shall have been paid. (1974 Code § 5-813; amd. 2010 Code)
7-1A-10: CIVIL LIABILITY:
Violators of this article shall be liable to the City for all costs and
expenses of remediation of the City public water system caused by such
violation. Such costs must be paid to the City before City water will be
supplied to such violator. (1974 Code § 5-814)
7-1A-11: VIOLATION; PENALTY:
   A.   Infraction: A violation of this article is hereby declared to be an
infraction. The violator, upon conviction, shall be subject to penalty as
provided in section
1-4-1 of this Code. Each twenty four (24) hour period the violation exists is a
separate violation. (Ord. 991, 10-11-2018)
   B.   Civil Action:
      1.   Whenever it appears to the City Council that any person has engaged
or is about to engage in any act or practice violating any provisions of this
article, the City Council may institute a civil action in the District Court to
enforce compliance with this article. Upon a showing that a person has engaged
or is about to engage in an act or practice constituting a violation of this
article, a permanent or temporary injunction, restraining order or other such
relief as the court deems appropriate may be granted. The City Council shall
not be required to furnish any bond in said civil processing.
      2.   The city may file a civil suit to collect all expenses and costs and
attorney fees the city incurred as a result of a violation of this article
which were not paid within ten (10) days after billing the same to the
violator.
      3.   The city shall be entitled to costs and reasonable attorney fees on
any suits brought to enforce this article or collect fees due the city. (1974
Code § 5-815)
ARTICLE B. PUBLIC AND INDUSTRIAL WELLS
SECTION:
7-1B-1: Purpose; Scope
7-1B-2: Definitions
7-1B-3: Use Of Private Well
7-1B-4: Drilling Of Private Well
7-1B-5: Drilling And Use Of Industrial Well
7-1B-6: Use Of Public Or Private Water Supply Required
7-1B-7: Utility Service Agreement
7-1B-1: PURPOSE; SCOPE:
The purpose of this article is to protect the public health of water consumers
by the control of actual and potential water contamination by private wells
located within the city limits. (1974 Code § 5-1101)
7-1B-2: DEFINITIONS:
As used in this article, the following words and terms shall have the meanings
ascribed to them in this section:
INDUSTRIAL WELL: A well used to supply water for an industrial use and not for
residential purposes. A well that is not a private well.
PRIVATE WELL: A well used to supply water for domestic use and irrigation water
for five (5) families or less, either as a single-family residence, multi-
family building or manufactured home subdivision or park. (1974 Code § 5-1102)
7-1B-3: USE OF PRIVATE WELL:
No private well will be maintained or used on any property within the city
limits or area of impact unless the same is allowed under section
7-1B-4 of this article. This prohibition does not apply to private wells in use
at the effective date hereof so long as said well is not abandoned and not used
for a period of six (6) consecutive months or more. (1974 Code § 5-1103; amd.
2010 Code; Ord. 2025-6, 3-24-2025)
7-1B-4: DRILLING OF PRIVATE WELL:
No private well shall be drilled within the city limits or area of impact after
the effective date hereof unless the closest city water main is two hundred
feet (200') or more away from the boundary line of the lot or parcel upon which
the water from said well will be used, measured from the boundary line closest
to the city water line to the city water main along the route the new water
line would have to be installed, in which case, the city will issue a written
city well permit for drilling said well. The water user shall be responsible
for the cost of the water line and all applicable costs if the city water line
is within two hundred feet (200') of said property and a private well is not
permitted. (1974 Code § 5-1104; amd. Ord. 2025-6, 3-24-2025)
7-1B-5: DRILLING AND USE OF INDUSTRIAL WELL:
The drilling and use of an industrial well shall not be allowed within the city
limits or area of impact unless the city elects to not supply water service or
is unable to do so. The drilling and use of an industrial well, if allowed,
shall be regulated and controlled by this title; the rules and regulations of
the Idaho department of water resources and the state of Idaho, as they now
exist or may hereafter be amended. (1974 Code § 5-1105. amd. Ord. 2025-6, 3-24-
2025)
7-1B-6: USE OF PUBLIC OR PRIVATE WATER SUPPLY REQUIRED:
   A.   It shall be unlawful to construct or maintain any private water source
or to connect to or use the city water system except as herein provided.
   B.   All houses, buildings or properties under the jurisdiction of the city
used for human occupancy, employment, recreation or other purposes that contain
facilities designed to supply water for human consumption shall connect such
facilities to a public or private water source conforming to the provisions
contained herein and no permit to construct a building shall be issued until
evidence has been submitted to the building official that the owner has
obtained a permit as provided herein to construct a private water supply or to
connect to a public water line for the purpose of water supply.
   C.   The owners of all new houses, buildings or properties abutting on any
street, alley or other right of way in which there is located a public water
line of the city, shall, at the owner’s expense, make the necessary line
extensions, connect to and use the water from the public water lines as
provided herein; providing, that said public water line is within two hundred
feet (200') of his property line.
   D.   The owners of all existing houses, buildings or properties served by a
private water supply shall, at the owner’s expense, abandon the private water
supply and make the necessary line extensions, connect to and use the water
from the public water line, at any time a public water line becomes available
for extension and/or connection within two hundred feet (200') of the property
line, providing the state department of health and welfare or the city water
superintendent notifies the owner, in writing, that the private water supply is
polluted.
   E.   The developer of a new subdivision shall, at his expense, construct the
necessary extensions of the public water system to provide a public water
supply for each lot in his subdivisions, providing the boundary line of the
subdivision is within one-half (½) mile of a public water line.
   F.   Notwithstanding the foregoing, the use of the city’s portable water
supply at the primary source of irrigation water in all new developments shall
be prohibited. For purposes of this subsection, the term “new development”
means any new subdivision or ZDA, or any development of any parcel or land of
two (2) acres or larger that is not part of a subdivisions or ZDA. (Ord. Ord.
2025-6, 3-24-2025)
7-1B-7: UTILITY SERVICE AGREEMENT:
Any owner of property outside the corporate limits of the city who desires to
connect ot a public water line shall first obtain approval of the public works
director and upon such approval shall sign a utility service agreement for
providing water service. Approval by the public works director shall be based
on the availability of surplus capacity in the public facility and the
council’s determination that the connection will not have a detrimental effect
on the health, safety or welfare of the other users of the water system. The
contract for providing water service shall, as a minimum, contain the following
provisions:
   A.   A request that the property served be annexed into the city immediately
upon becoming contiguous to said city.
   B.   An agreement to comply with all policies, rules and regulations
governing the water system and to pay all fees and charges for services
provided all as established herein.
   C.   An agreement to comply with all provisions of the building, zoning and
subdivision regulations of this code; except, that the requirements for a city
issued building permit shall not apply to property which is not then eligible
for annexation.
   D.   An acknowledgment that the use of the public water system is granted
only because surplus capacity is available and agreement that such use may be
terminated by the city council at any time said council determines that such
surplus capacity is no longer available or determines the terms of the
agreement are not being complied with by the owner.
   E.   Notwithstanding the foregoing, the use of the city’s potable water
supply as the primary source or irrigation water in all new developments shall
be prohibited. For purposes of this subsection, the term “new development”
means any new subdivision or ZDA, or any development of any parcel of land of
two (2) acres or larger that is not part of a subdivisions or ZDA. (Ord. 2025-
6, 3-24-2025
CHAPTER 2
SEWER SYSTEM RATES AND REGULATIONS
ARTICLE A. PUBLIC AND PRIVATE SEWERS
SECTION:
7-2A-1: Definitions
7-2A-2: Private Sewage Disposal
7-2A-3: Building Sewers And Connections
7-2A-4: Use Of Public Sewers
7-2A-5: Stop Flow Valves
7-2A-6: Maintenance Of Sewer Service Lines
7-2A-7: Industrial Waste Discharges, Cost
7-2A-8: Protection From Damage
7-2A-9: Inspectors
7-2A-10: Violation; Penalty
7-2A-1: DEFINITIONS:
Unless the context specifically indicates otherwise, the meaning of terms used
in this article and in article B of this chapter, shall be as follows:
BOD (DENOTING BIOCHEMICAL OXYGEN DEMAND): The quantity of oxygen utilized in
the biochemical oxidation of organic matter under standard laboratory
procedures in five (5) days at twenty degrees Celsius (20°C), expressed in
parts per million by weight.
BUILDING DRAIN: The part of the lowest horizontal piping of a drainage system
which receives the discharge from soil, waste and other drainage pipes inside
the walls of the building and conveys it to the building sewer, beginning five
feet (5') outside the inner face of the building wall.
BUILDING SEWER: The extension from the building drain to the public sewer or
other place of disposal.
COMBINED SEWER: A sewer receiving both surface runoff and sewage.
GARBAGE: Solid wastes from the preparation, cooking and dispensing of food, and
from the handling, storage and sale of produce.
INDUSTRIAL WASTES: The liquid wastes from industrial processes as distinct from
sanitary sewage.
NATURAL OUTLET: Any outlet into a watercourse, pond, ditch, lake or other body
of surface water or groundwater.
pH: The logarithm of the reciprocal of the weight of hydrogen ions in grams per
liter of solution.
PROPERLY SHREDDED GARBAGE: The wastes from the preparation, cooking and
dispensing of food that has been shredded to such a degree that all particles
will be carried freely under the flow conditions normally prevailing in public
sewers, with no particle greater than one-half inch (1/2") in any dimension.
PUBLIC SEWER: A sewer in which all owners of abutting properties have equal
rights, and is controlled by public authority.
SANITARY SEWER: A sewer which carries sewage and to which stormwater, surface
water and groundwaters are not intentionally admitted.
SEWAGE: A combination of the water carried wastes from residences, business
buildings, institutions and industrial establishments, together with such
groundwater and stormwaters as may be present.
SEWAGE TREATMENT PLANT: Any arrangement of devices and structures used for
treating sewage.
SEWAGE WORKS: All facilities for collecting, pumping, treating and disposing of
sewage.
SEWER: A pipe or conduit for carrying sewage.
SHALL; MAY: Shall is mandatory; may is permissive.
STORM SEWER OR STORM DRAIN: A sewer which carries stormwater and surface water
and drainage, but excludes sewage and polluted industrial wastes.
SUPERINTENDENT: The superintendent of sewage works of the city, or his
authorized deputy, agent or representative.
SUSPENDED SOLIDS: Solids that either float on the surface of, or are in
suspension in water, sewage or other liquids, and which are removable by
laboratory filtering.
WATERCOURSE: A channel in which a flow of water occurs, either continuously or
intermittently. (1974 Code § 5-901)
7-2A-2: PRIVATE SEWAGE DISPOSAL:
   A.   Permitted: Where a public sanitary or combined sewer is not available
under the provisions of section
7-2A-4 of this article, the building sewer shall be connected to a private
disposal system complying with the provisions of the South Central health
district. (1974 Code § 5-902; amd. 2010 Code)
   B.   When Permit Becomes Effective: A permit for a private sewage disposal
system shall not become effective until the installation is completed to the
satisfaction of the superintendent. He shall be allowed to inspect the work at
any stage of construction and, in any event the applicant for the permit shall
notify the superintendent when the work is ready for final inspection, and
before any underground portions are covered. The inspection shall be made
within forty eight (48) hours of the receipt of notice by the superintendent.
   C.   Compliance Required: The type, capacities, location and layout of a
private sewage disposal system shall comply with all recommendations of the
department of public health of the state of Idaho. No permit shall be issued
for any private sewage disposal system employing subsurface soil absorption
facilities where the area of the lot is less than ten thousand (10,000) square
feet. No septic tank or cesspool shall be permitted to discharge to any public
sewer or natural outlet.
   D.   Availability Of Public Sewer: At such time as a public sewer becomes
available to a property served by a sewage disposal system, as provided in
article B of this chapter, a direct connection shall be made to the public
sewer in compliance with this article, any septic tanks, cesspools and similar
private sewage disposal facilities shall be abandoned and filled with suitable
material.
   E.   Operation And Maintenance: The owner shall operate and maintain the
private sewage disposal facilities in a sanitary manner at all times, at no
expense to the city.
   F.   Additional Requirements: No statement contained in this section shall
be construed to interfere with any additional requirements that may be imposed
by the appropriate officials of the state of Idaho or county of Twin Falls.
(1974 Code § 5-902)
7-2A-3: BUILDING SEWERS AND CONNECTIONS:
   A.   Written Permit; Fee:
      1.   Required: No unauthorized person shall uncover, make any connection
with or opening into, use, alter, or disturb any public sewer or appurtenances
thereof without first obtaining a written permit from the superintendent.
      2.   Classes Of Permits: There shall be two (2) classes of building sewer
permits:
         a.   For residential and commercial service; and
         b.   For service establishments producing industrial wastes.
      3.   Application: In either case, the owner or his agent shall make
application on a special form furnished by the city. The permit application
shall be supplemented by any plans, specifications or other information
considered pertinent in the judgment of the superintendent. (1974 Code § 5-903)
      4.   Permit And Inspection Fee: A permit and inspection fee as
established for residential, commercial and industrial building sewer permits
by the international building code shall be paid to the city clerk-treasurer at
the time the application is filed. (1974 Code § 5-903; amd. 2010 Code)
   B.   Installation Costs And Expenses; Indemnification: All costs and expense
incident to the installation and connection of the building sewer shall be
borne by the owner. The owner shall indemnify the city from any loss or damage
that may directly or indirectly be occasioned by the installation of the
building sewer. (1974 Code § 5-903)
   C.   Separate And Independent Building Sewer Required: A separate and
independent building sewer shall be provided for every building. (1974 Code §
5-903; amd. 2010 Code)
   D.   Old Building Sewers: Old building sewers may be used in connection with
new buildings only when they are found, on examination and test by the
superintendent, to meet all requirements of this article. (1974 Code § 5-903)
   E.   Material Specifications: Material specifications for building sewers
shall be as provided in the "Idaho Standards For Public Works Construction",
2008 edition. (1974 Code § 5-903; amd. 2010 Code)
   F.   Size And Slope: The size and slope of the building sewer shall be
subject to the approval of the superintendent, but in no event shall the
diameter be less than four inches (4"). The slope of such four inch (4") pipe
shall not be less than one-fourth inch (1/4") per foot, the slope of six inch
(6") pipe shall be not less than one-eighth inch (1/8") per foot.
   G.   Elevation: Whenever possible, the building sewer shall be brought to
the building at an elevation below the basement floor. No building sewer shall
be laid parallel to or within three feet (3') of any bearing wall, which might
thereby be weakened. The depth shall be sufficient to afford protection from
frost. The building sewer shall be laid at uniform grade and in straight
alignment insofar as possible. Changes in direction shall be made only with
properly curved pipe and fittings.
   H.   Drain Too Low; Lifting Required: In all buildings in which any building
drain is too low to permit gravity flow to the public sewer, sanitary sewage
carried by such drain shall be lifted by approved artificial means and
discharged to the building sewer.
   I.   Excavations: All excavations required for the installation of a
building sewer shall be open trench work unless otherwise approved by the
superintendent. Pipe laying and backfill shall be performed in accordance with
ASTM specifications C12-19 except that no backfill shall be placed until the
work has been inspected.
   J.   Joints And Connections:
      1.   All joints and connections shall be made gastight and watertight.
(1974 Code § 5-903)
      2.   All joints and connections shall be made as provided in the "Idaho
Standards For Public Works Construction", 2008 edition. (1974 Code § 5-903;
amd. 2010 Code)
      3.   All joints in pipe shall be of a type approved by the
superintendent.
   K.   Connection To Public Sewer: The connection of the building sewer into
the public sewer shall be made at the Y branch, if such branch is available at
a suitable location. If no properly located Y branch is available, a neat hole
may be cut into the public sewer to receive the building sewer, with entry in
the downstream direction at an angle of about forty five degrees (45°). A forty
five degree (45°) ell may be used to make such connection, with the spigot end
cut so as not to extend past the inner surface of the public sewer. The invert
of the building sewer at the point of connection shall be at the same or at a
higher elevation than the invert of the public sewer. A smooth, neat joint
shall be made, and the connection made secure and watertight by encasement in
concrete. Special fittings may be used for the connection only when approved by
the superintendent.
   L.   Notice For Inspection: The applicant for the building sewer permit
shall notify the superintendent when the building sewer is ready for inspection
and connection to the public sewer. The connection shall be made under the
supervision of the superintendent or his representative.
   M.   Excavations; Barricades And Lights Required: All excavations for
building sewer installation shall be adequately guarded with barricades and
lights so as to protect the public from hazard. Streets, sidewalks, parkways
and other public property disturbed in the course of the work shall be restored
in a manner satisfactory to the city. (1974 Code § 5-903)
7-2A-4: USE OF PUBLIC SEWERS:
   A.   Protection Of Sewage System: No person shall discharge or cause to be
discharged any stormwater, surface water, groundwater, roof runoff, subsurface
drainage, cooling water or unpolluted industrial process waters to any sanitary
sewer.
   B.   Unpolluted Drainage: Stormwater and all other unpolluted drainage shall
be discharged to such sewers as are specifically designated as combined sewers
or storm sewers, or to a natural outlet approved by the superintendent.
Industrial cooling waters or unpolluted process waters may be discharged, upon
approval of the superintendent, to a storm sewer, combined sewer or natural
outlet.
   C.   Prohibited Discharges: Except as hereinafter provided, no person shall
discharge or cause to be discharged any of the following described waters or
wastes to any public sewer:
      1.   Any liquid or vapor having a temperature higher than one hundred
fifty degrees Fahrenheit (150°F).
      2.   Any water or waste which may contain more than one hundred (100)
parts per million by weight, of fat, oil or grease.
      3.   Any gasoline, benzene, naphtha, fuel oil or other flammable or
explosive liquid, solid or gas.
      4.   Any waters or wastes having a pH lower than 5.5 or higher than 9.0
or having any other corrosive property capable of causing damage or hazard to
structures, equipment and personnel of the sewer works.
      5.   Any waters or wastes containing a toxic or poisonous substance in
sufficient quantity to injure or interfere with any sewage treatment process,
constitute a hazard to humans or animals, or create any hazard in receiving
waters of the sewage treatment plant.
      6.   All waters or wastes containing suspended solids of such character
and quantity that unusual attention or expense is required to handle such
materials at the sewage treatment plant.
      7.   Any noxious or malodorous gas or substance capable of creating a
public nuisance. (1974 Code § 5-904)
      8.   Antibiotics, other prescription drugs, or anything else that could
be deemed by the federal government to put the city out of effluent compliance.
(2010 Code)
   D.   Grease, Oil And Sand Interceptors:
      1.   Required: Grease, oil and sand interceptors shall be provided when,
in the opinion of the superintendent, they are necessary for the proper
handling of liquid wastes containing grease in excessive amounts, or any
flammable wastes, sand and other harmful ingredients; except that such
interceptors shall not be required for private living quarters or dwelling
units. All interceptors shall be of a type and capacity approved by the
superintendent, and shall be located as to be readily and easily accessible for
cleaning and inspection.
      2.   Maintenance: Where installed, all grease, oil and sand interceptors
shall be maintained by the owner, at his expense, in continuously efficient
operation at all times.
   E.   Preliminary Treatment Facilities:
      1.   Required: The admission into the public sewers of any waters or
wastes having: a) a five (5) day biochemical oxygen demand greater than three
hundred (300) parts per million by weight, or b) containing more than three
hundred fifty (350) parts per million by weight of suspended solids, or c)
containing any quantity of substances having the characteristics described in
subsection C of this section, or d) having an average daily flow greater than
two percent (2%) of the average daily sewage flow of the city shall be subject
to the review and approval of the superintendent. Where necessary, in the
opinion of the superintendent, the owner shall provide, at his expense, such
preliminary treatment as may be necessary to: a) reduce the biochemical oxygen
demand to three hundred (300) parts per million and the suspended solids to
three hundred fifty (350) parts per million by weight, or b) reduce
objectionable characteristics or constituents to within the maximum limits
provided for in subsection C of this section, or c) control the quantities and
rates of discharge of such waters or wastes. Plans, specifications and other
pertinent information relating to proposed preliminary treatment facilities
shall be submitted for the approval of the superintendent and of the state
board of health of the state of Idaho and no construction of such facilities
shall be commenced until said approvals are obtained, in writing.
      2.   Maintenance: Where preliminary treatment facilities are provided for
any waters or wastes, they shall be maintained continuously in satisfactory and
effective operation by the owner at his expense.
   F.   Control Manhole: When required by the superintendent, the owner of any
property served by a building sewer carrying industrial wastes shall install a
suitable control manhole in the building sewer to facilitate observation,
sampling and measurement of the wastes. Such manhole, when required, shall be
accessibly and safely located, and shall be constructed in accordance with
plans approved by the superintendent. The manhole shall be installed by the
owner at his expense, and shall be maintained by him so as to be safe and
accessible at all times.
   G.   Measurements, Tests And Analyses: All measurements, tests and analyses
of the characteristics of waters and wastes (reference made thereto in
subsections C and F of this section) shall be determined in accordance with
"Standard Methods For The Examination Of Water And Sewage" and shall be
determined at the control manhole provided for in subsection F of this section,
or upon suitable samples taken at said control manhole. In the event that no
special manhole has been required, the control manhole shall be considered to
be the nearest downstream manhole in the public sewer to the point at which the
building sewer is connected.
   H.   Special Agreements Or Arrangements: No statement contained in this
section shall be construed as preventing any special agreement or arrangements
between the city and any industrial concern whereby an industrial waste of
unusual strength or character may be accepted by the city for treatment,
subject to payment therefor by the industrial concern. (1974 Code § 5-904)
7-2A-5: STOP FLOW VALVES:
   A.   Required: All plumbing installations for sewer connections from
buildings within the city to the sewer service lines of the city which require
openings into the sewer service lines within the same elevation as the main
sewer line, or which are basement sewer line connections, or which are from
single level buildings which may be determined to be within a critical distance
of any lift station on said main sewer line of the city, such distance to be
determined by the city engineer, shall be required to have installed on said
sewer connection line, an antiflowback sewer collection line, and such
antiflowback valve shall be located in an accessible location for cleaning and
repair by the owner.
   B.   Inspection And Approval Of Building Inspector: The city shall inspect
all building permit applications to determine whether or not such building
sewer connection to the main sewer line is within a category above specified,
and if so, the owner of said premises shall be notified of the requirements
hereof, and prior to completion of such sewer line connection, the said line
shall be inspected and approved by the city building inspector.
   C.   Required Prior To Connection: No premises hereafter erected or to be
hereafter connected to the sewer collection system of the city shall be allowed
to connect the sewer effluent line to the main collection system prior to
installation of the antiflowback valve as herein provided and inspection by the
prior official to the city.
   D.   Size And Capacity: All antiflowback valves to be installed as herein
required shall be of sufficient size and capacity to ensure operation and shall
be maintained at all times in operable condition by the owner of the premises.
(1974 Code § 5-905)
7-2A-6: MAINTENANCE OF SEWER SERVICE LINES:
   A.   Responsibility For Maintenance:
      1.   City: The city shall maintain and repair all sewer main lines and
collector lines which are located on or within any city street, alley or
dedicated easement, which maintenance and repair shall include replacement,
elimination of leaking lines, blockage of any kind not specifically provided
for in subsections A2 and B2 of this section.
      2.   Property Owner: Every person, within the city, whether as owner,
tenant, occupant, lessee or otherwise, shall maintain the individual sewer
connection from the building or buildings served thereby to the tap on the city
main sewer line or city collector line as the case may be. This maintenance
shall include repair and replacement as required, elimination of leaking lines,
blockage of any kind and rodding as provided in subsection B2 of this section.
   B.   Removal Of Roots Or Any Other Blockage:
      1.   Sewer Main Lines And Collector Lines: The city shall remove any
blockages from all main sewer lines and collector lines within the city which
are not designated in subsection B2 of this section to be the responsibility of
the property owner.
      2.   Sewer Service Lines: The person, within the City, whether as owner,
tenant, occupant, lessee or otherwise shall have the responsibility of removal
of all roots and rodding or removal of any blockages in the service line from
the building or buildings served by the individual sewer service line to the
tap on the City main sewer line or City collector line as the case may be.
   C.   Responsibilities Of City Sewer Superintendent: The Superintendent of
the Sewer Department shall have the responsibility to investigate any and all
problems that develop within the City and determine the responsibility for
maintenance, repair and rodding of the sewer lines pursuant to this section.
The location of the leak, roots, breakage, blockage or cloggage shall determine
the responsibility for such maintenance or repair as the case may be. (1974
Code § 5-906)
7-2A-7: INDUSTRIAL WASTE DISCHARGES, COST:
The City Council shall develop and adopt, by resolution, an industrial cost
recovery system acceptable to the United States Environmental Protection Agency
and which shall comply with Pub.L. 92-500 and all regulations and guidelines
pertaining thereof. Industrial wastes shall be and are hereby defined to be
those wastes as defined under section
305-905-8 of the Construction Grant Regulations in 40 Code of Federal
Regulations, part 35. (1974 Code § 5-907)
7-2A-8: PROTECTION FROM DAMAGE:
No unauthorized person shall maliciously, wilfully or negligently break,
damage, destroy, uncover, deface or tamper with any structure, appurtenance or
equipment which is a part of the Municipal sewage works. Any person violating
this provision shall be subject to immediate arrest under charge of disorderly
conduct. (1974 Code § 5-908)
7-2A-9: INSPECTORS:
The Superintendent and other duly authorized employees of the City bearing
proper credentials and identification shall be permitted to enter upon all
properties for the purposes of inspection, observation, measurement, sampling
and testing in accordance with the provisions of this article. (1974 Code § 5-
909)
7-2A-10: VIOLATION; PENALTY:
   A.   Notice Of Violation: Any person found to be violating any provision of
this article, except section
7-2A-9 of this article, shall be served by the City with written notice stating
the nature of the violation and providing a reasonable time limit for the
satisfactory correction thereof. The offender shall, within the period of time
stated in such notice, permanently cease all violations. (1974 Code § 5-910)
   B.   Failure To Comply: Any person who shall continue any violation beyond
the time limit provided for in this section shall be deemed guilty of an
infraction and, upon conviction, subject to penalty as provided in section
1-4-1 of this Code; provided, however, that in the event the damages resulting
from a violation of this section exceed five hundred dollars ($500.00), such
person shall be guilty of a misdemeanor. (Ord. 991, 10-11-2018)
ARTICLE B. SEWER SERVICE FEES
SECTION:
7-2B-1: Sewer Fund
7-2B-2: Utility Accounts
7-2B-3: Billing; Payment
7-2B-4: Method Of Collection (Rep. by Ord. 966, 10-22-2012)
7-2B-5: Application For Sewer Service Connection; Fees
7-2B-6: Rates And Charges
7-2B-7: Service Outside City Limits
7-2B-1: SEWER FUND:
   A.   Created: There shall be and there is hereby created in the office of
the city clerk-treasurer a special fund which shall be known and described as
the sewer fund, into which fund shall be placed such revenues as may from time
to time be directed by ordinance and which revenues shall be deposited in said
sewer fund, and from which fund shall be paid such charges as may be directed
by the mayor and council.
   B.   Collected Fees And Charges: All fees and charges herein provided, when
collected, shall be placed in the sewer fund and paid into the general fund of
the city. (1974 Code § 5-1001)
7-2B-2: UTILITY ACCOUNTS:
The city clerk-treasurer shall establish an account for all premises consisting
of each individual lot, piece or parcel of property, dwelling, flat, rooming
house, eating place, shop, place of business, manufacturing, or business
establishment in the city. (1974 Code § 5-1002)
7-2B-3: BILLING; PAYMENT:
   A.   Billing To Individual Accounts: All sewer, and similar monthly charges
shall be billed to the individual account for the premises to which such
service is rendered as part of the utility fee billed as provided hereafter in
chapter 5 of this title. (Ord. 966, 10-22-2012)
7-2B-4: METHOD OF COLLECTION:
(Rep. by Ord. 966, 10-22-2012)
7-2B-5: APPLICATION FOR SEWER SERVICE CONNECTION; FEES:
   A.   Applicants Within City: Owners of property located within the city
shall make application for connection to the city sewer system and shall pay a
connection fee as follows:
      1.   Application: Application for connection to the city sewer system
must be made at the office of the city clerk-treasurer on such forms as the
clerk-treasurer may prescribe. The application must be made by the owner or
tenant of the property to be benefited and state the lots and blocks on which
it is to be used. Said applicant must agree to conform to the rules and
regulations established from time to time, as a condition for service
connection. At the time of making the application, said applicant for sewer
installation shall make payment of the applicable connection fee. (1974 Code §
5-1005)
      2.   Fees: At the time of the application for permit to connect to the
sewer service and system of the city, there shall be paid a hookup fee set by
resolution adopted by the city council and approved by the mayor. (Ord. 950, 9-
13-2010)
   B.   Applicants Outside City: Owners of property located outside the city
shall make application for connection to the city sewer system and shall pay a
connection fee as follows:
      1.   Application: Application for connection to the city sewer system
must be made at the office of the city clerk-treasurer on such forms as the
clerk-treasurer may prescribe. The application must describe the property to be
benefited. The application shall be submitted to the city council for its
approval prior to any connection being so permitted. (1974 Code § 5-1005)
      2.   Fees: Upon approval by the city council of the requested connection,
the applicant shall pay a connection or hookup fee set by resolution adopted by
the city council and approved by the mayor, which payment shall be made prior
to connection. The applicant shall be responsible for all costs in construction
of the service line on applicant's property and extension of city main line or
connection line that may be required to provide service to applicant's
property. (Ord. 950, 9-13-2010)
7-2B-6: RATES AND CHARGES:
   A.   Charges Established:
      1.   Residential: The monthly charges for city sewer service for each
dwelling unit serviced by the city sewer system shall be set by resolution of
the city council. The residential rates shall apply to residential single-
family dwellings only. For multiple dwelling units, being apartments, duplexes,
motels, trailer parks, rooming houses or any other multiple-family dwelling
units within the city, a monthly charge per unit, or equivalent, shall be
charged for such sewer service.
      2.   Commercial: The monthly charges for city sewer service shall be
determined by the amounts of city water delivered to the premises as shown by
the water meter from private sources delivered to the premises, as shown by a
meter supplied by the owner, and which is discharged into the public sewer; and
shall be collected at the rates set by resolution of the city council.
      3.   Cost Considerations: In setting the rates, the city council shall
consider the costs of providing said services and the costs of maintaining and
improving the city services.
      4.   Commercial Users To Supply Meters: All commercial users shall supply
adequate meters for all private water sources used on their premises, or in
lieu thereof, provide an adequate meter for the wastewater from their premises
entering the city sewer collection system.
      5.   Applicability Of Commercial Rate: Commercial rates shall apply not
only to business houses and commercial users in the commercial areas or
industrial areas of the city, but shall also apply to those dwellings used for
commercial purposes located in any area of the city.
   B.   Premises With No Water Delivery: Rates and charges for premises to
which city water is not delivered, except as above specified, or metered, or
upon which sewer service has no reasonable relationship with water delivered or
used upon the premises shall be affixed according to the rates and charges for
the same or similar use and occupancy in other cases. Where applicable,
wastewater meters shall be used to determine applicable rates for such uses.
(1974 Code § 5-1006)
   C.   Months When Water Services Discontinued: No charge shall be made for
the month or months for which the city water services for such premises has
been discontinued pursuant to section
7-5-2 of this title; provided, further that such period of time is not less
than one month and provided further that upon notice of such vacancy, and in
such event, no charge will be made during the time the premises are vacant, and
no sewage is collected therefrom. (1974 Code § 5-1006; amd. 2010 Code)
   D.   Modification Of Rates And Charges: The rates and charges herein
established shall be subject to modification upon application to the city
council by the owner or occupant of any premises in any cases when fees so
established shall be, in the opinion of the city council, unjust or oppressive.
(1974 Code § 5-1006)
7-2B-7: SERVICE OUTSIDE CITY LIMITS:
All owners outside the city who derive benefit from the city sewer system
shall, in return for said benefits, pay monthly sewer service rates and charges
equal to one and one-half (11/2) of that monthly charge otherwise chargeable to
an owner within the city and as computed and collected under this article. Such
service shall be covered by contract between the city and the users of the city
sewer system. (1974 Code § 5-1007)
ARTICLE C. SEWER LINE CONSTRUCTION
SECTION:
7-2C-1: Construction Permit
7-2C-2: Construction Of Pipeline
7-2C-3: Cost Sharing Of Construction
7-2C-4: Previously Constructed Sewer Lines
7-2C-5: Conflict With Subdivision Ordinance
7-2C-1: CONSTRUCTION PERMIT:
Any person desiring to construct a sewer trunk line to be connected onto the
city sewage disposal system shall first obtain a permit for such construction
upon application being filed with the city engineer. The said application for
permit shall be filed with the city engineer and shall state the name of the
person applying, the approximate location of the sewer trunk line to be
constructed, and the legal description of the land or lots to be served by the
line and the owner of the said lots or land so served, together with the
proposed size of the pipeline and type of material of the pipe to be laid and
the approximate cost. (1974 Code § 3-1301)
7-2C-2: CONSTRUCTION OF PIPELINE:
Upon approval by the mayor and city council, the person making application for
construction of a sewer pipeline must, at his cost, construct a sewer pipeline
under the specifications and direction of the city engineer in such a manner
that there are sufficient connecting junctions or Ys constructed so as to serve
the adjacent lots or lands by which the sewer line passes, and also sufficient
manholes as specified. Upon completion of the sewer line, the person
constructing the same and the city engineer shall file a certificate of
completion with the city clerk-treasurer setting forth the following:
   A.   Location of the sewer;
   B.   The lots served;
   C.   The owner of lots served;
   D.   The construction costs per lots served;
   E.   The frontage foot of each lot served;
   F.   The owners of lots who have participated in the cost of construction;
   G.   A proposal for sharing of the construction costs with persons owning
lands which may be subsequently benefited by connecting onto the sewer line as
constructed. (1974 Code § 3-1302)
Once installed and accepted by the city, the sewer line shall become the
property of the city. (1974 Code § 3-1302; amd. 2010 Code)
7-2C-3: COST SHARING OF CONSTRUCTION:
No person owning lots or lands shall be served by such sewer trunk line, nor
connected onto that line, until he has paid the pro rata costs of the
construction of the said sewer line. All persons desiring to connect to said
sewer must make application to the building inspector for the city and present
verification of payment of said pro rata cost to the person having constructed
the sewer line or his assigns. No building permit authorizing the connection to
the sewer line shall be issued until the said pro rata cost has been paid.
(1974 Code § 3-1303)
7-2C-4: PREVIOUSLY CONSTRUCTED SEWER LINES:
All persons having heretofore constructed sewer lines at their expense may file
with the city clerk-treasurer a certificate of completion as provided in
section
7-2C-2 of this article for cost sharing of that construction shall be
applicable. (1974 Code § 3-1304)
7-2C-5: CONFLICT WITH SUBDIVISION ORDINANCE:
It is intended that in the event any of the provisions of this article should
conflict with the provisions of title 9, chapter 24 of this code regarding the
construction of sewer lines by a developer within a subdivision, that the
provisions as set forth in the subdivision ordinances shall be controlling.
(1974 Code § 3-1305)
CHAPTER 3
GARBAGE COLLECTION AND DISPOSAL
SECTION:
7-3-1: Definitions
7-3-2: Police Power Exercised
7-3-3: City To Haul Or Contract To Haul
7-3-4: Classification
7-3-5: Accumulation Of Garbage And Rubbish
7-3-6: Streets And Private Property To Be Kept Clean
7-3-7: Containers
7-3-8: Items Excluded From City Collection
7-3-9: Hauling Vehicles
7-3-10: Burning Of Garbage
7-3-11: Sanitary Disposal Area
7-3-12: Fees
7-3-13: Scope Of Service Charge
7-3-14: Billing And Payment For Service
7-3-15: Disposition Of Monies From Collection And Disposal Service
7-3-16: Enforcement
7-3-17: Violation; Penalty
7-3-1: DEFINITIONS:
As used in this chapter, the following words and terms shall have the meanings
ascribed to them in this section:
GARBAGE: Kitchen refuse from residences and places where food is prepared for
human consumption and all animal and vegetable refuse from such kitchens and
other places, and offal from fish, meat and vegetable markets and all organic
substances of every kind and nature unfit for food and subject to quick decay.
PERSON: Includes a normal person, his heirs, executors, administrators and
assigns, and shall include a firm, partnership or corporation, its or their
successors or assigns. Singular includes plural. Male includes female.
RUBBISH: Floor sweepings, broken crockery, broken bottles, dishes and
glassware, broken bricks, tin vessels, trimmings from lawns and flower gardens,
paper sacks, straw, sawdust, packing material, and shavings. Pasteboard boxes
and berry boxes will be included as "rubbish" as herein defined when they have
been broken down to such a size that they will fit into the receptacles
required by the city to be furnished.
SHALL AND MAY: "Shall" means mandatory. "May" means permissive. (1974 Code § 5-
301; amd. 2010 Code)
7-3-2: POLICE POWER EXERCISED:
This chapter will be deemed an exercise of the police power of the city, acting
in its governmental capacity, for the protection of the health, welfare, safety
and cleanliness of said city and all its provisions shall be liberally
construed for the accomplishment of its purpose. (1974 Code § 5-302; amd. 2010
Code)
7-3-3: CITY TO HAUL OR CONTRACT TO HAUL:
   A.   Exclusive Right: The city, its duly authorized agents, contractors,
servants, employees or licensees shall have the exclusive right to gather and
collect garbage and rubbish within the city, and it shall be unlawful for any
person, firm or corporation, except as otherwise provided in this chapter, to
collect or gather garbage and/or rubbish within the city. (1974 Code § 5-303)
   B.   City May Haul Or Contract:
      1.   All garbage or rubbish from residential homes, units or apartments
will be hauled by the city in its own vehicles by its employees; however, the
city may, but need not, issue a permit or license to any person, firm or
corporation with adequate equipment to contract the hauling of garbage, trash,
or rubbish from commercial firms or buildings only, with the owner or occupant
thereof; provided, however, that such contractor must make his service
available to any and all commercial accounts.
      2.   Notwithstanding the provisions of subsection B1 of this section, the
city council may, at its sole discretion, enter into an agreement with a
commercial unit only whereby the city and the commercial unit agree that the
city will furnish no garbage collection service whatsoever to said commercial
unit and that the commercial unit will haul all of its own garbage and rubbish.
(1974 Code § 5-304; amd. 2010 Code)
7-3-4: CLASSIFICATION:
   A.   Residential: A residential unit is a single-family dwelling or an
apartment of two (2) units or less where no business or commercial activity is
performed on the premises.
   B.   Commercial: A commercial unit shall be placed where a business activity
is conducted on the premises. Where a residence is combined with a business in
the same building or premises, it shall be classified as commercial. (1974 Code
§ 5-305)
   C.   Apartments, Mobile Homes, Duplexes: Apartments, residences and trailers
or mobile homes, duplexes or otherwise shall be considered as commercial units
defined in subsection B of this section. (1974 Code § 5-305; amd. 2010 Code)
   D.   Churches And Civic And Fraternal Order Buildings: All churches, civic
and fraternal order buildings, not having a regular schedule of meal service,
shall be classified as a residential unit. (1974 Code § 5-305)
7-3-5: ACCUMULATION OF GARBAGE AND RUBBISH:
   A.   Prohibited: No person shall deposit, collect or accumulate nor permit
the deposit, collection or accumulation of any garbage, rubbish or other refuse
upon any open place, land, lot or premises, nor upon any alley or street within
the city, except as herein provided.
   B.   Right Of Entry: The city shall have the right to enter any lots, lands
or premises or any alleys or streets adjacent thereto within the city and
remove any and all debris, garbage, rubbish, and other refuse accumulated
thereon and charge such cost of removal to the owner or occupant, if such owner
or occupant fails to remove the same, after being given five (5) days' notice
by the sanitation officer of the city to so remove such debris, garbage or
other refuse. The city shall have a lien against the real property for such
costs.
   C.   Warning Notices; Failure To Comply; Civil Penalty; Lien: The city,
through its employees, may also issue warning notices for any violation of this
chapter which shall set forth a time limit to correct such violation and the
date for reinspection. If the violation is not corrected by the reinspection
date set on the warning notice, a civil penalty of one hundred dollars
($100.00) shall be assessed for the first violation, two hundred dollars
($200.00) for the second violation, and three hundred dollars ($300.00) for the
third and subsequent violations during the same calendar year. The city shall
have a lien against the real property for such civil penalty.
   D.   Service Of Notice: Notice shall be deemed as being completed when
mailed by certified mail addressed to such owner or occupant.
   E.   Cost Of Removal And/Or Civil Penalty:
      1.   The cost of such removal and/or any civil penalty shall be charged
to the owner or occupant and will be payable in the same manner as all other
utility accounts with said city.
      2.   The cost of such removal and/or any civil penalty not collected by
the city with utility accounts may be collected by being certified to the
county assessor or other proper county officer having charge of making up of
the assessment rolls, such assessment to be placed on the assessment rolls and
collected in the same manner as other municipal taxes are collected. (1974 Code
§ 5-306)
7-3-6: STREETS AND PRIVATE PROPERTY TO BE KEPT CLEAN:
It shall be unlawful for any person, firm or corporation to deposit any
rubbish, garbage, litter, or other noxious matter in any street, avenue,
alleyway, park, or parking strip. It shall be unlawful for any person, firm or
corporation to distribute, hand out, drop, throw, cast or discard wastepaper,
paper wrappings, sacks, cartons, wrapping paper, in, upon or about any streets,
alleys, sidewalks, avenues or public places, or in or upon any motor vehicle or
in open spaces or vacant lots, or in yards or stoops of privately owned
premises in the city. (1974 Code § 5-307)
7-3-7: CONTAINERS:
No person shall deposit garbage or rubbish on or below the surface of the
ground in a manner otherwise than herein prescribed. No person shall deposit or
bury any garbage or rubbish in or upon a public alley, street, other public
area, or upon the premises of another person, whether or not the garbage or
rubbish is in a prescribed container. No garbage, dirt or rubbish of any kind
shall be thrown, swept or pushed into the street in front of any place of
business or residence, except on permission of the city sanitation officer, and
the proprietor of the business and the owner or occupant of the premises shall
be responsible for the disposal of all such garbage or rubbish. (1974 Code § 5-
308)
   A.   Receptacles Furnished By City: Every owner, agent or occupant of every
building or residence is hereby provided a ninety (90) gallon, hard plastic
tote to each residence in which shall be placed all rubbish accumulated in such
building, residence or on such premises; provided, that the term rubbish as
used in this section does not include broken or discarded stoves or furniture,
broken or discarded building materials, paper, ash, grass, weeds, lawn
clippings, brush, leaves or any waste material accumulated outside the dwelling
house within any residence, building or warehouse district. (1974 Code § 5-308;
amd. 2010 Code)
   B.   Location Of Containers For Pick Up:
      1.   Alley Available: Where an alley is available, containers for garbage
and all types of rubbish shall be located on the private premises adjacent to
the property line on the alley, and at a point readily accessible to the
collectors. No garbage container or rubbish containers or piles of rubbish
shall be placed in or upon the alley right of way.
      2.   No Alley Available: Where no alley is available, containers or
rubbish shall be placed in front of the premises by the owners or the occupants
of such premises on the morning of the day scheduled for collection; and the
empty containers shall be withdrawn from the front of the premises as soon
after collection as possible on the same day. (1974 Code § 5-308)
7-3-8: ITEMS EXCLUDED FROM CITY COLLECTION:
   A.   Ashes, dirt or earth debris from construction or lawn renovation,
rocks, stones, automobile bodies and parts, manure, offal or waste materials
from animals, dead animals, building materials, such as mortar, plaster, scrap
lumber and wood shavings, must be collected and disposed of by the building
contractor, owner or occupant of premises. (1974 Code § 5-310; amd. 2010 Code)
   B.   "Hazardous materials" as defined by the laws of the United States and
the state of Idaho, and materials containing asbestos, paints, paint thinners,
turpentine, insecticide, herbicides, pesticides and all other chemicals.
   C.   Motor vehicle batteries and tires. (1974 Code § 5-310)
7-3-9: HAULING VEHICLES:
It shall be unlawful for any person, firm or corporation to remove and haul any
garbage and rubbish from the city, excepting in vehicles so constructed as to
prevent leakage therefrom of garbage and so covered as to prevent escape
therefrom or rubbish. (1974 Code § 5-311)
7-3-10: BURNING OF GARBAGE:
   A.   Rules For Open Burning: The international fire code section 307 as
adopted by the state of Idaho requires notification of the fire department and
the securing of an open burning permit. The following items must be addressed
in order to secure a permit:
      1.   Notification: Notification of the fire department prior to
commencement of open burning.
      2.   Material Restrictions: See department of environmental quality
regulations. General restrictions cover items such as tires, twine, asphalt
shingles, etc. It is usually permissible to burn tree limbs, grass, weeds, etc.
      3.   Time And Atmospheric Conditions: Open burning shall only be
conducted during the times and atmospheric conditions as set by the fire
department.
         a.   Times: Seven o'clock (7:00) A.M. through seven o'clock (7:00)
P.M.
         b.   Wind: Less than twelve (12) miles per hour.
      4.   Location: No open burning shall be conducted within twenty five feet
(25') of any structure or other combustible material.
      5.   Attendance: All open burning shall be attended at all times by a
competent adult knowledgeable in the methods of extinguishment.
      6.   Fire Extinguishing Equipment: A garden hose connected to a water
supply or other approved fire extinguishing equipment shall be readily
available for use at open burning sites.
      7.   Discontinuance: The Chief or his representative is authorized to
require that open burning be immediately discontinued if it is determined that
smoke emissions are offensive or dangerous conditions exist.
   B.   Failure To Comply: Failure to comply with these rules may result in
citation under the International Fire Code section 109.2.3 (prosecution).
   C.   Obtaining Burning Permit: To obtain an open burning permit call 543-
5664. If the station is not staffed at the time of your call, you may log your
permit (if you comply with the stated provisions) by following the voice mail
prompts for burning permits. Listen to the message and leave the requested
information.
